His expertise in fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) and tafsir (Quranic exegesis) made him a respected figure among his contemporaries. His scholarly works continue to be studied and referenced in the fields of Islamic studies and jurisprudence.

0864Jazairi.bio: Jazairi was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply immersed in the study and teaching of the Quran and Hadith. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology were profound, with his works serving as essential references for scholars and students alike. Jazairi's dedication to the dissemination of Islamic knowledge was evident through his rigorous teaching schedule and the numerous texts he authored, which continue to be studied for their insightful analysis and interpretation of Islamic principles. His scholarly pursuits were driven by a deep commitment to faith and an unwavering dedication to intellectual inquiry.

0864RadiDinGhazzi.bio: Radi Din Ghazzi, a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence, made significant contributions to the field of Shafi'i law. His extensive knowledge and deep understanding of Islamic legal principles allowed him to author several influential works. Among his notable contributions is his detailed commentary on the Minhaj al-Talibin, a key text in Shafi'i jurisprudence. His writings not only enriched Islamic legal scholarship but also served as essential references for scholars and students alike. His expertise in Islamic law was widely recognized, making him a respected figure among his contemporaries.

0866MuhammadIbnSayyidHasan.bio: Muhammad Ibn Sayyid Hasan was a distinguished scholar whose contributions to Islamic thought and jurisprudence have been acknowledged by peers and students alike. His works, deeply rooted in the rich traditions of Islamic scholarship, reflect a profound understanding of the complexities of Islamic law and theology. Through his writings, he sought to address and elucidate the pressing religious and legal questions of his time, offering insights that continue to be studied and revered in Islamic academic circles.

0868IbnCumarBulqini.bio: Ibn Cumar Bulqini was a distinguished Islamic scholar within the Shafi'i school of jurisprudence. His profound understanding and interpretation of Islamic law and theology were widely recognized. He authored several influential works that contributed significantly to Islamic jurisprudence and legal theory. His writings are still referenced by scholars and students of Islamic law today, showcasing his deep knowledge and analytical skills in addressing complex religious and legal issues. His contributions to the Shafi'i madhhab are particularly notable, enriching the intellectual and spiritual landscape of Islamic scholarship.

0869IbnKhalilZaynDinQabuni.bio: Ibn Khalil Zayn Din Qabuni, also known as Ibn al-Sheikh Khalil, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and literature are well-regarded. He hailed from the Qabun area, aligning him with the rich scholarly tradition of the region. His works, deeply rooted in the principles of Islamic law, reflect a profound understanding of the Shafi'i school of thought. His scholarly endeavors provided valuable insights into the complexities of Islamic jurisprudence, making him a respected figure among his contemporaries and scholars who followed.

0870Jazuli.bio: Jazuli is renowned for his significant contributions to Islamic spirituality and literature. He is best known for compiling the Dala'il al-Khayrat, a widely celebrated collection of prayers on the Prophet Muhammad. This work has played a crucial role in the spread of the Sufi tradition across the Muslim world, embedding itself deeply in the devotional practices of countless Muslims. His efforts in spiritual writings have made him a revered figure in the realm of Islamic mysticism, with his works continuing to inspire and guide the faithful in their spiritual journeys.

0871IbnAhmadShamsDinBacuni.bio: Ibn Ahmad Shams Din Bacuni was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist. He dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic jurisprudence, contributing significantly to the Hanbali school of thought. His works, deeply rooted in Islamic tradition, explore various aspects of Islamic law and ethics. Among his notable contributions is his commentary on the Quran, which is celebrated for its insightful analysis and depth of understanding. Bacuni's scholarly efforts have made him a respected figure in Islamic academic circles, with his writings continuing to be a valuable resource for scholars and students alike.

0871IbnCuthmanShamsDinMardini.bio: Ibn Cuthman Shams Din Mardini was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist within the Shafi'i school of thought. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-regarded, with his works being studied and referenced by scholars and students alike. He hailed from Mardin, reflecting his deep roots in the rich intellectual and cultural heritage of the region. His scholarly pursuits and writings have left a lasting mark on the study and practice of Islamic law, showcasing his profound understanding and interpretation of Islamic principles and jurisprudence.

0871MuhammadCuqbani.bio: Muhammad Cuqbani, known in Arabic as محمد بن العقباني, was a distinguished Islamic jurist hailing from Tlemcen. His scholarly contributions are deeply rooted in the Maliki school of thought, through which he articulated and expanded upon Islamic jurisprudence. His works, primarily focused on legal theory and practice, served as significant references for scholars and students within the Maliki tradition. Cuqbani's dedication to Islamic law and his methodical approach to jurisprudence highlight his profound understanding and respect for the intricacies of Islamic legal principles.

0871TaqiDinIbnFahd.bio: Taqi Din Ibn Fahd was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Mecca, belonging to the Hashemite family. He was deeply versed in Islamic jurisprudence, history, and hadith, making significant contributions to these fields. His works are considered essential references in Islamic studies, particularly those concerning the legal opinions and history of Mecca. Among his notable works is a comprehensive history of Mecca, which remains a vital source for scholars studying the holy city and its religious significance. His scholarly efforts were rooted in the Shafi'i school of thought.

0872IdrisCimadDin.bio: Idris Cimad Din was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply immersed in the study and teaching of Islamic sciences. His contributions spanned various fields, including Hadith, Fiqh, and Islamic jurisprudence, making him a revered figure among his contemporaries. He dedicated his life to the pursuit of knowledge, engaging in scholarly debates and writing extensively on complex religious matters. His works, characterized by their depth and insight, served as valuable resources for both his peers and future generations of scholars.

0872Zahiri.bio: Al-Ẓāhirī, Ghars al-Dīn Khalīl b. Shāhīn, was a distinguished Islamic scholar who made significant contributions to the field of Islamic jurisprudence. His works primarily focused on the Zahiri school of thought, which emphasizes adherence to the literal meanings of the Quran and Hadith. Al-Ẓāhirī's scholarly efforts were dedicated to expounding and defending the principles of this school, aiming to clarify and apply its teachings in the context of Islamic law. His writings continue to be studied for their rigorous approach to Islamic legal theory.

0873AbuZaydThacalibi.bio: Abu Zayd Thacalibi was a distinguished scholar in the fields of Arabic literature and history. His contributions include a rich collection of works that explore the intricacies of the Arabic language, poetry, and the cultural heritage of the Arab world. Among his notable works is 'Yatimat al-Dahr', a comprehensive anthology of Arabic poetry that spans various themes and epochs. Thacalibi's writings are celebrated for their eloquence, depth of knowledge, and the insight they provide into the literary and historical contexts of his time.

0873IbnShahinZahiri.bio: Ibn Shahin Zahiri was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic tradition, known for his deep insights and contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and hadith studies. His works are considered a valuable asset in understanding the complexities of Islamic law and prophetic traditions. Among his notable contributions, his efforts in compiling and explaining hadiths stand out, providing clarity and depth to the Islamic scholarly community. His dedication to the preservation and interpretation of Islamic texts has made his works a reference point for scholars and students alike.

0874BadrDinIbnQadiShuhba.bio: Badr Din Ibn Qadi Shuhba was a distinguished historian and Shafi'i jurist based in Damascus. He is renowned for his scholarly contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and history. Among his notable works is the 'Tarikh al-Sham', a comprehensive history of Syria, which has been a vital source for researchers studying the region's Islamic and social history. His expertise in Shafi'i jurisprudence also led him to author several key texts that have been influential in the study and practice of Islamic law.

0874IbnImamKamiliyya.bio: Ibn Imam Kamiliyya, formally known as Kamal al-Din Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic world. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, theology, and philosophy. Despite the challenges of his era, he managed to author several influential works that were highly regarded among his contemporaries. His writings not only showcased his profound knowledge and understanding of Islamic law and principles but also reflected his deep commitment to the intellectual and spiritual development of the Muslim community.

0874IbnTaghribirdi.bio: Ibn Taghribirdi, al-Atabaki, was an Egyptian historian of the Mamluk era. He is renowned for his detailed chronicles of Islamic history, particularly the Mamluk Sultanate. His most famous work, 'al-Nujum al-Zahira fi Muluk Misr wa'l-Qahira,' offers an exhaustive account of the political, social, and cultural landscape of Egypt and Cairo from the Islamic conquest until his time. His writings serve as a crucial source for researchers studying the Mamluk period, providing insights into the complexities of governance, military campaigns, and the lives of notable figures during his era.

0875Husayni.bio: Husayni was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply immersed in the study and teaching of Hadith, Islamic jurisprudence, and theology. His intellectual pursuits led him to author several influential texts that explored the intricacies of Islamic law and the interpretation of the Quran. His works are characterized by a meticulous approach to scholarship, combining rigorous analysis with a profound understanding of the Islamic tradition. Husayni's contributions to Islamic scholarship were marked by his dedication to preserving the purity of Islamic teachings while engaging with the complex legal and theological issues of his time.

0875IbnMuhammadShihabDinHijazi.bio: Ibn Muhammad Shihab Din Hijazi, known for his profound scholarship in Islamic jurisprudence and history, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His works, deeply rooted in the rich traditions of Islamic thought, offer insightful analyses and interpretations of Islamic law and history. His contributions are celebrated for their depth and scholarly rigor, reflecting his deep commitment to the study and dissemination of Islamic knowledge. His writings continue to be a valuable resource for scholars and students of Islamic studies, showcasing his mastery over a wide range of Islamic disciplines.

0875Jizi.bio: Al-Jizi was an Islamic scholar who made significant contributions to the fields of Arabic grammar and linguistics. His works focused on the intricacies of Arabic syntax and morphology, aiming to clarify and codify the rules governing the Arabic language. Through his scholarly efforts, he sought to provide a comprehensive understanding of Arabic grammar, which was instrumental for students and scholars alike. His dedication to the study of Arabic linguistics has been recognized by his contemporaries and later generations of scholars, making his contributions a valuable part of the Islamic scholarly tradition.

0877CaliNabatiCamili.bio: Cali Nabati Camili, known in Arabic as الشيخ علي النباطي and also as علي بن يونس العاملي, was a distinguished scholar whose contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-regarded. His works, deeply rooted in the principles of Shi'a Islam, explore complex theological issues and offer insights into the jurisprudential challenges of his time. His scholarly output includes a range of texts that continue to be studied for their depth of knowledge and analytical rigor.

0877IbnMiftah.bio: Ibn Miftāḥ, formally known as Abū al-Ḥasan ʿAbd Allāh b. Abī al-Qāsim b. Miftāḥ, was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and philosophy were profound, with his works often delving into intricate aspects of fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) and usul al-fiqh (principles of Islamic jurisprudence). His intellectual pursuits were not limited to jurisprudence; he also explored theological concepts, making significant contributions to the discourse on faith and reason within the Islamic tradition. His writings, characterized by their depth and insight, continue to be studied and revered in Islamic scholarly circles.

0879IbnMuhammadIbnAmirHajj.bio: Ibn Amir Hajj, formally known as Shams al-Din Muhammad ibn Muhammad, was a distinguished scholar in the Hanafi school of Islamic jurisprudence. He authored several influential works, most notably his comprehensive guide on Hajj rituals and practices, which served as a pivotal reference for Muslims undertaking the pilgrimage. His expertise extended beyond jurisprudence, contributing significantly to the fields of Islamic ethics and theology. His writings, characterized by their clarity and depth, continue to be studied and respected in Islamic scholarly circles.

0879IbnQutlubugha.bio: Ibn Quṭlūbuġā, formally known as Zayn al-dīn Abū al-Fidāʾ Qāsim b. Quṭlūbuġā al-Sūdūnī, al-Ǧamālī, al-Ḥanafī, was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist within the Hanafi school of thought. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and history are well-regarded, with his works serving as reference points for scholars and students alike. Among his notable works are detailed commentaries and treatises on Islamic law, which have been instrumental in the education and guidance of Muslim jurists and scholars throughout the Islamic world.

0879MuhyiDinKafiyaji.bio: Muhyi Din Kafiyaji, originally named Muhammad ibn Sulayman ibn Sa'd ibn Mas'ud, was a distinguished scholar in the field of Arabic language and literature. Hailing from a background deeply rooted in the Hanafi school of Islamic jurisprudence, he made significant contributions through his works. Among his notable contributions is the development and refinement of Arabic rhetoric, which has been influential in the study and teaching of Arabic eloquence. His expertise in the nuances of the Arabic language has made his works a staple in the curriculum of students pursuing Islamic and Arabic studies.

0880IbnAhmadShamsDinAsyuti.bio: Ibn Ahmad Shams Din Asyuti was an Egyptian Islamic scholar, historian, and jurist, renowned for his profound knowledge in various Islamic sciences. He authored numerous works that spanned Quranic exegesis, Hadith, Islamic jurisprudence, Arabic language, and history. Among his notable contributions are comprehensive commentaries on the Quran and Hadith collections, which have been widely referenced and studied in Islamic scholarship. His works are characterized by their depth, precision, and scholarly rigor, making him a distinguished figure in Islamic academic circles.

0880IbnCabdWahidMaymuni.bio: Ibn Cabd Wahid Maymuni was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the rich traditions of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His scholarly pursuits were primarily focused on the interpretation and understanding of Islamic texts, contributing significantly to the body of Islamic knowledge through his writings. His works, characterized by their depth and insight, served as valuable resources for scholars and students alike. Maymuni's dedication to Islamic scholarship was evident in his meticulous approach to research and his commitment to preserving the integrity of Islamic teachings.

0880IbnCadilHanbali.bio: Ibn 'Adil al-Hanbali, a distinguished Islamic scholar from Damascus, was renowned for his deep expertise in Hanbali jurisprudence. His scholarly contributions include a comprehensive commentary on the Quran, which has been celebrated for its insightful analysis and depth of knowledge. His works reflect a profound understanding of Islamic law and theology, making him a respected figure among scholars and students of Islam. His dedication to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences has left a lasting mark on the Hanbali school of thought.

0882IbnAhmadShadhiliTunisi.bio: Ibn Ahmad Shadhili Tunisi was a Maliki scholar from Tunisia who later settled in Cairo. He is recognized for his contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and Sufism. His works reflect a deep understanding of Maliki law and Sufi practices, bridging the gap between legalistic approaches and spiritual dimensions of Islam. Among his notable contributions is his commentary on Maliki law, which has been a valuable resource for scholars and students alike. His life was dedicated to teaching and writing, making significant contributions to the fields of Islamic law and spirituality.

0882LisanDinIbnShihnaHalabi.bio: Lisan Din Ibn Shihna Halabi was a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence, particularly within the Hanafi school of thought. His expertise extended to various fields, including history and language, making him a versatile figure in Islamic scholarship. He authored several influential works that contributed significantly to Islamic legal studies and historiography. His writings, characterized by depth and clarity, served as essential references for scholars and students alike. His contributions to the Hanafi legal tradition and his scholarly works remain valued for their intellectual rigor and comprehensive analysis.

0883AbuBakrJuraci.bio: Abu Bakr Juraci, known in Arabic as الجراعي, was a distinguished scholar in the Hanbali school of Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic legal thought and religious studies are well-regarded, with his works continuing to be referenced by scholars and students of Islamic law. Juraci's expertise was not limited to jurisprudence; he was also knowledgeable in the fields of hadith and theology. His scholarly pursuits were deeply rooted in the traditions of the Hanbali school, reflecting a commitment to the principles and methodologies established by earlier Islamic scholars.

0883ShihabDinBinNasrDaci.bio: Shihab Din Bin Nasr Daci was a distinguished Islamic scholar and historian. His contributions to the field of Islamic history are notable for their depth and scholarly insight. Daci's works often focused on the historical events and figures of the Islamic world, providing detailed accounts that have been valuable for both contemporary and later scholars. His meticulous approach to historical documentation has made his writings a significant resource for understanding the complexities of Islamic history.

0884AbuDharrSibtIbnCajami.bio: Abu Dharr Sibt Ibn Cajami was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic world. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, theology, and history. He was known for his deep understanding of Islamic law and its application, as well as his ability to interpret and explain complex theological issues. His works, which include commentaries on the Quran and Hadith, remain influential in Islamic scholarship. His dedication to teaching and writing helped spread knowledge and understanding of Islamic principles during his time.

0884AbuIshaqIbnMuflih.bio: Abu Ishaq Ibn Muflih was a distinguished Islamic scholar within the Hanbali school of jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic legal thought are encapsulated in his seminal works, which continue to be referenced for their depth and clarity. Among his notable contributions is the comprehensive legal manual 'Al-Furu'' which systematically outlines the Hanbali legal code. His dedication to the principles of Islamic jurisprudence and his meticulous approach to legal issues have made his works essential reading for scholars and students of Islamic law.

0885BurhanDinBiqaci.bio: Burhan al-Din Abu al-Hasan Ibrahim b. Umar al-Biqa'i was a distinguished Islamic scholar known for his deep insights into Quranic exegesis. His most notable work, 'Nazm al-Durar fi Tanasub al-Ayat wa al-Suwar,' is a comprehensive study that explores the interconnections between Quranic verses and chapters, showcasing his innovative approach to understanding the Quran. Al-Biqa'i's contributions extend beyond exegesis; he also engaged in the fields of hadith, Islamic law, and Arabic language, demonstrating his versatility and depth of knowledge in Islamic sciences.

0885CalaDinMardawi.bio: Ala' al-Din Abu al-Hasan Ali ibn Sulaiman al-Mardawi, a distinguished Hanbali jurist and legal theorist, is renowned for his comprehensive work on Hanbali jurisprudence. His magnum opus, 'Al-Insaf fi Ma'rifat al-Rajiha min al-Khilaf 'ala Madhhab al-Imam Ahmad ibn Hanbal,' is a critical examination of differing opinions within the Hanbali school, aiming to identify the most reliable positions. This work is celebrated for its depth and clarity, making it a cornerstone in the study of Hanbali law. Al-Mardawi's contributions are pivotal in the codification and systematization of Hanbali jurisprudence.

0885IbnFahd.bio: Ibn Fahd, Najm al-Dīn ʿUmar b. Muḥammad b. Muḥammad al-Makkī, was a distinguished Islamic scholar and historian based in Mecca. He is renowned for his contributions to the historiography of Mecca, with his most notable work being 'Ithāf al-warā bi-akhbār Umm al-Qurā'. This comprehensive history of Mecca serves as a vital reference for scholars studying the Islamic holy city. His writings offer detailed accounts of Mecca's religious, social, and architectural development, reflecting his deep engagement with the city's history and significance in the Islamic world.

0885IbnFaramurzMullaKhusraw.bio: Ibn Faramurz Mulla Khusraw, also known as Muhammad ibn Faramurz, was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist. He is renowned for his profound contributions to Hanafi jurisprudence. Among his notable works, his commentary on Al-Hidayah stands out as a seminal text, deeply influencing Islamic legal studies. His expertise was not limited to fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) alone; he also made significant contributions to other areas of Islamic sciences, including hadith and tafsir (Quranic exegesis). His scholarly works continue to be a reference for students and scholars in the field of Islamic studies.

0889IbnAhmadSakhawi.bio: Ibn Ahmad Sakhawi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and historian, renowned for his expertise in hadith and biographical evaluation. He authored several influential works, including 'Al-Daw al-Lami` for the A'yan al-Qarn al-Hadi,' a comprehensive biographical dictionary of notable figures in the 8th Hijri century. His meticulous approach to documentation and critique of hadith narrators established him as a pivotal figure in Islamic scholarship. Sakhawi's contributions extend to various fields of Islamic studies, making his works essential references for scholars and students alike.

0889IbnCabdMuncimShamsDinQahiri.bio: Ibn Cabd Muncim Shams Din Qahiri was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist within the Shafi'i school of thought. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and his scholarly works have been recognized for their depth and insight. He was deeply rooted in the traditions of Islamic scholarship, engaging with the complexities of Islamic law and ethics. His works reflect a profound understanding of the Shafi'i madhhab, showcasing his expertise in fiqh. His scholarly pursuits were dedicated to exploring and elucidating the intricacies of Islamic jurisprudence, making significant contributions to the field.

0889IbnQawan.bio: Ibn Qawan was a notable scholar whose contributions to Islamic thought and literature have been recognized by scholars and academics. His works, though not extensively documented in contemporary sources, have been referenced in various historical texts, indicating their influence and importance in the study of Islamic sciences. Despite the scarcity of detailed records about his life, Ibn Qawan's intellectual legacy is appreciated for its depth and insight, reflecting the rich scholarly traditions of his time.

0891AhmadBakri.bio: Ahmad Bakri was a distinguished Islamic scholar and historian, renowned for his profound contributions to Islamic literature. His works encompassed a wide range of subjects, including jurisprudence, theology, and history, reflecting his versatile scholarship. Bakri's writings are celebrated for their depth of knowledge and clarity, making significant contributions to the Islamic intellectual tradition. His meticulous research and insightful analysis have made his works valuable resources for scholars and students alike. Through his scholarly endeavors, Bakri played a crucial role in preserving and interpreting the rich heritage of Islamic thought.

0893CamiriHaradi.bio: Al-ʿĀmirī al-Ḥaraḍī, also known as Yaḥyá b. Abī Bakr b. Muḥammad al-ʿĀmirī al-Yamanī al-Ḥaraḍī, was a distinguished scholar from Yemen. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, history, and theology. Al-ʿĀmirī al-Ḥaraḍī is renowned for his in-depth analysis and commentary on Islamic texts, which have been referenced by scholars for centuries. His works are considered essential reading for those interested in the intricacies of Islamic law and the historical context of its development.

0893IbnAbiBakrCayniHanafi.bio: Ibn Abi Bakr Cayni Hanafi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist within the Hanafi school of thought. His expertise spanned various Islamic sciences, including Hadith, Fiqh, and Islamic history. He is best known for his comprehensive work on the principles of Hadith, which served as a critical resource for scholars in Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic legal theory and his analytical approach to the Hadith literature have been highly regarded by scholars and students of Islamic studies.

0893IbnAhmadZaynDinSharji.bio: Ibn Ahmad Zayn Din Sharji, also known as Zayn al-Din al-Zabidi, was a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence. His expertise was deeply rooted in the Shafi'i school of thought, where he contributed significantly through his writings and teachings. Among his notable works, his commentary and elucidation on the seminal texts of Islamic jurisprudence stand out, serving as essential references for scholars and students alike. His scholarly efforts were dedicated to clarifying complex legal principles and making them accessible to a broader audience.

0893IbnIsmacilShihabDinKurani.bio: Ibn Ismacil Shihab Din Kurani was a distinguished scholar who transitioned from the Shafi'i to the Hanafi school of thought during his lifetime. His intellectual journey and contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-documented. He engaged deeply with the works of previous scholars, offering critical insights and interpretations that enriched the Islamic scholarly tradition. His writings, though not specified here, continue to be studied for their depth and insight into the complexities of Islamic law and spirituality.

0893Manawi.bio: Manawi, known as أبو الهمم نور الدين علي المناوي in Arabic, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic literature are vast, with his works encompassing hadith, tafsir, and Islamic jurisprudence. Among his notable works, the commentary on Al-Jami' al-Saghir by Jalaluddin al-Suyuti stands out for its depth and insight, making it a valuable resource for scholars and students of Islam. Manawi's scholarly efforts were dedicated to elucidating complex Islamic principles and making them accessible to a broader audience.

0894CabdRahmanSufuri.bio: Cabd Rahman Sufuri was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the rich traditions of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His scholarly contributions are vast, encompassing a wide range of Islamic sciences. Among his notable works, his meticulous commentaries and interpretations of Islamic texts stand out, serving as valuable resources for scholars and students alike. Sufuri's dedication to the dissemination of Islamic knowledge was evident through his teachings and writings, which continue to be referenced for their depth of insight and clarity in explaining complex Islamic principles.

0894IbnMuhammadDimashqiHaydari.bio: Ibn Muhammad Dimashqi Haydari, also known as Al-Khaydari, was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Damascus. He is renowned for his contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His works often delved into the intricacies of Islamic law and Sufism, reflecting a deep understanding of the Sharia and the spiritual path. Among his notable contributions is a commentary on the Quran, which has been celebrated for its insightful analysis and depth of knowledge. His scholarly output remains a valuable resource for those studying Islamic sciences and spirituality.

0894IbnQasimRassacTunisi.bio: Ibn Qasim Rassac Tunisi was a Tunisian Maliki scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and scholarship are notable, particularly in the Maliki school of thought. He authored several works that have been influential in the study and practice of Islamic law. His expertise in jurisprudence and his dedication to teaching and writing have made his works a valuable resource for scholars and students of Islamic law. His scholarly efforts were focused on interpreting and applying the principles of the Maliki school to the challenges and questions of his time.

0895AbuCabdAllahSanusi.bio: Abu Cabd Allah Sanusi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and mystic, renowned for his profound contributions to Sufi thought. He founded the Sanusiyya Sufi order, which emphasized a return to the pure teachings of Islam, advocating for a life of simplicity and devotion. His works and teachings significantly influenced the spiritual and social dimensions of Muslim communities, particularly in North Africa. Sanusi's emphasis on community welfare, education, and the establishment of zawiyas (religious schools and retreats) played a crucial role in spreading his reformist ideas.

0895SibtMaridini.bio: Sibt Maridini, formally known as Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Ahmad al-Ghazal al-Dimashqi, was a distinguished scholar in the fields of astronomy and mathematics. He is best known for his comprehensive works on astronomical tables and his efforts to simplify complex astronomical calculations for wider understanding. His contributions include detailed explanations of the use of astrolabes, a critical tool during his time for navigating the stars. His work served as a bridge between classical astronomical wisdom and the emerging needs of his contemporary society, making complex celestial calculations more accessible.

0896AbuHamidMaqdisi.bio: Abu Hamid Maqdisi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and historian, renowned for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and history. His scholarly work primarily focused on the principles of Shafi'i jurisprudence, earning him a revered place among Islamic jurists. Maqdisi's extensive travels across the Islamic world allowed him to gather a wealth of knowledge, which he meticulously documented in his writings. His dedication to the preservation and interpretation of Islamic law and history has made his works a valuable resource for scholars and students of Islam.

0896IbnCaliIbnAzraqGharnati.bio: Ibn Cali Ibn Azraq Gharnati was a distinguished historian and jurist from Granada. He is best known for his comprehensive work on the history and legal traditions of the Nasrid dynasty. His meticulous documentation of events, legal opinions, and judicial decrees provides a valuable insight into the socio-political and legal landscape of Granada during his time. His writings are considered crucial for understanding the complexities of Andalusian society and the Islamic legal framework within the context of the Nasrid era.

0897IbnYusufCabdariGharnati.bio: Ibn Yusuf Cabdari Gharnati, also known as Al-Mawaq, was a distinguished Maliki jurist and scholar from Granada. He is renowned for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and his mastery in various Islamic sciences. His works, deeply rooted in the Maliki school of thought, serve as significant references for scholars and students alike. Among his notable contributions is his commentary on the Mudawwana, a foundational text in Maliki fiqh, which showcases his deep understanding and insightful analysis of Islamic legal principles.

0898NurDinJami.bio: Nur Din Jami was a Persian scholar, poet, and Sufi mystic. He is renowned for his contributions to Persian literature and Sufi philosophy. Among his most celebrated works are 'Yusuf and Zulaikha,' a poetic rendition of the Quranic story of Joseph and Potiphar's wife, and 'Baharistan,' a collection of short stories. Jami also compiled 'Nafahat al-Uns,' which details the lives of Sufi saints, further cementing his role in the spiritual and literary traditions of the Islamic world.

0899Rajraji.bio: Al-Rajraji, formally known as Al-Hussein ibn Ali, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic tradition. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, theology, and history. He hailed from a lineage of scholars and continued the legacy by engaging deeply in the intellectual debates of his time. His works, characterized by their depth and insight, served as significant references for scholars who followed. Al-Rajraji's scholarly pursuits were not confined to a single region, reflecting the interconnectedness of the Islamic scholarly tradition across different lands.

0899ZarruqShihabDinFasi.bio: Zarruq Shihab Din Fasi, a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence and mysticism, made significant contributions to Sufism. He is renowned for his comprehensive works on spirituality and ethics, which blend legalistic perspectives with Sufi practices. His most celebrated work, 'Qawa'id al-Tasawwuf' (Principles of Sufism), serves as a foundational text in understanding the spiritual path within Islam. His teachings emphasized the importance of sincerity, the observance of Islamic law, and the pursuit of inner purification. Through his writings and teachings, he provided a structured approach to Sufi practice that continues to influence Islamic spirituality.

0900Anonymous.bio: This figure remains enigmatic due to the lack of personal details and the anonymity surrounding their identity. Despite this, their contributions to the intellectual and cultural landscapes of their time are undeniable. The absence of a known name does not diminish the value of their works, which continue to be studied and appreciated for their insights and depth. Their writings, preserved through meticulous transcription and translation, offer a window into the thoughts and philosophies of a period rich in scholarly activity.

0900CabdAllahBadri.bio: Cabd Allah Badri was a distinguished Islamic scholar who made significant contributions to the field of Hadith studies. His work involved the meticulous collection, verification, and compilation of Hadiths, which are sayings, actions, or approvals of the Prophet Muhammad. Badri's efforts in authenticating and categorizing these narratives have been crucial for Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His scholarly rigor and dedication to preserving the integrity of Islamic teachings have earned him a respected place among Islamic scholars.

0900IbnCabdMuncimHimyari.bio: Ibn ʿAbd al-Munʿim al-Ḥimyarī was a distinguished historian and geographer whose contributions to the fields of history and geography are still referenced today. He is best known for his detailed accounts of the geographical and cultural aspects of the Islamic world. His works provide a comprehensive insight into the urban and rural life of his time, including descriptions of cities, towns, and regions, as well as the customs and practices of their inhabitants. His meticulous documentation serves as a valuable resource for scholars seeking to understand the historical and geographical context of the Islamic world.

0900IbnMuhammadBurhanDinQabibati.bio: Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Mahmud ibn Badr, known as Burhan al-Din, Abu Ishaq al-Halabi al-Qabibati al-Shafi'i al-Naji, was a distinguished Islamic scholar in the Shafi'i school of jurisprudence. He hailed from Aleppo, known for his profound knowledge and contributions to Islamic jurisprudence. His works, deeply rooted in the Shafi'i methodology, served as essential references for scholars and students alike. His dedication to Islamic law and its principles made him a respected figure among his contemporaries in the Islamic scholarly community.

0900IbnMuhammadNurDinAshmuni.bio: Ibn Muhammad Nur Din Ashmuni was a distinguished scholar in the Shafi'i school of Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic legal thought and jurisprudence were significant, with his works serving as reference points for scholars and students alike. Ashmuni's expertise was not limited to fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence); he was also well-versed in other Islamic sciences, which allowed him to approach Islamic law with a comprehensive understanding. His writings continue to be studied for their depth of knowledge and insight into the Shafi'i madhhab.

0900IbnSulaymanHilli.bio: Ibn Sulayman Hilli, formally known as Al-Hasan ibn Sulayman al-Hilli, was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Hilla, a city renowned for its scholarly heritage. He made significant contributions to Shia Islamic jurisprudence and was deeply involved in the intellectual debates of his time. His works often delved into the intricacies of Islamic law, ethics, and theology, reflecting a profound understanding of the religious texts. Among his notable contributions, his efforts to articulate and defend the principles of Shia Islam stand out, showcasing his scholarly rigor and dedication to his faith.

0900ImamHadiCizzDinIbnHasan.bio: Imam Hadi Cizz Din Ibn Hasan was a distinguished Islamic scholar and theologian. He dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences, contributing significantly to the fields of Hadith, Fiqh, and Tafsir. His scholarly works are highly regarded in Islamic academic circles for their depth of knowledge and insight. He was known for his rigorous approach to scholarship and his ability to articulate complex Islamic principles in a manner that was accessible to a broad audience. His writings continue to be a source of guidance and inspiration for students and scholars of Islam.

0900MuflihIbnRashid.bio: Muflih Ibn Rashid was an Islamic scholar whose contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are noted for their depth and insight. His works, often characterized by a meticulous approach to the analysis of religious texts, have been influential in the development of Islamic legal thought. Muflih's writings, which include extensive commentaries on the Quran and Hadith, serve as a critical resource for scholars and students of Islam. His ability to reconcile complex legal and theological issues with the practical aspects of faith has made his work a cornerstone in the study of Islamic jurisprudence.

0900MuflihSaymari.bio: Muflih Saymari was a distinguished Islamic scholar, known for his profound contributions to the field of Hadith studies. His expertise in the authentication and compilation of Hadiths made him a respected figure among his contemporaries. Saymari's work primarily focused on the collection and verification of Hadiths, ensuring their accuracy for future generations. His dedication to preserving the sayings and actions of the Prophet Muhammad was evident through his meticulous approach to scholarship. His writings continue to be a valuable resource for scholars and students of Islamic studies.

0902Sakhawi.bio: Shams Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Sakhawi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and historian, renowned for his expertise in hadith and biographical evaluation. He authored several influential works, including 'Al-Daw' al-Lami' for the A'yan of the century,' a comprehensive biographical dictionary of notable figures in the Islamic world during his time. Al-Sakhawi's meticulous documentation of scholars and their contributions has been invaluable for subsequent generations, providing a rich source of Islamic history and scholarship. His dedication to preserving the legacy of Islamic scholars has cemented his reputation in Islamic studies.

0904Burayhi.bio: Al-Burayhī, formally known as ʿAbd al-Wahhāb b. ʿAbd al-Raḥmān al-Burayhī al-Saksakī al-Yamanī, was a distinguished scholar from Yemen. His contributions to Islamic scholarship are noted for their depth and breadth, encompassing various aspects of Islamic studies. Al-Burayhī's works are characterized by their meticulous research and clarity, making them valuable resources for scholars and students alike. His writings continue to be studied and respected for their scholarly merit and insight into the Islamic tradition.

0905Basrawi.bio: Basrawi, originally named علي بن يوسف بن علي بن أحمد, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic tradition. He hailed from Damascus but was famously known by his nisba relating to Basra. A follower of the Shafi'i school of thought, his contributions spanned various aspects of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His works, deeply rooted in the classical Islamic sciences, reflect a profound engagement with the religious texts and a meticulous approach to legal and theological issues. His scholarly output remains a reference for students and scholars of Islamic studies.

0905IbnCabdAllahWaqqadAzhari.bio: Ibn Cabd Allah Waqqad Azhari, also known as Khalid bin Abdullah Al-Azhari, was a distinguished scholar in the fields of Arabic language and literature. His contributions to the understanding and teaching of Arabic grammar and morphology were significant. Among his notable works, his commentary and elucidation on key texts in Arabic grammar stand out for their depth and clarity. Al-Azhari's expertise also extended to the sciences of the Quran and Hadith, where he applied his linguistic skills to interpret Islamic texts. His scholarly works continue to be referenced in the study of Arabic linguistics.

0905IbnCabdRahmanIjiShafici.bio: Shihab al-Din Ahmad al-Shafi'i al-Iji, known as Ibn 'Abd Rahman Iji Shafici, was a distinguished Islamic scholar in the fields of theology, logic, and jurisprudence. He is best known for his work 'Al-Mawaqif fi 'Ilm al-Kalam,' which is considered a seminal text in Islamic theology. This work, along with 'Al-Risala al-Shamsiyya' in logic, showcases his profound understanding and contribution to Islamic scholarship. His writings continue to be a reference point for scholars interested in the intricate details of Islamic theology and logic.

0905IbnCaliTaqiDinKafcami.bio: Ibn Cali Taqi Din Kafcami, known in Arabic as الكفعمي, was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist. He authored several influential works that continue to be studied and revered in the fields of Islamic jurisprudence and spirituality. Among his notable contributions are comprehensive texts on supplications and rituals, which have served as essential guides for Muslims seeking to deepen their religious practices. His writings, characterized by their depth and clarity, have made a significant mark on Islamic literature, particularly in the Shia tradition.

0905KamalDinQudsi.bio: Kamal Din Qudsi, originally named Kamal Din Muhammad ibn Abi Sharif al-Qudsi, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-documented in his numerous writings. He was deeply engaged in the intellectual debates of his time, focusing on the intricacies of Islamic law and ethical conduct. His works remain a reference for scholars seeking to understand the complexities of Islamic legal and moral philosophy.

0906IbnMajid.bio: Ibn Māǧid was a master navigator and cartographer whose expertise in the arts of navigation and astronomy guided sailors through the Indian Ocean's treacherous waters. His comprehensive knowledge of the stars and sea currents enabled him to author several works on maritime navigation, including the famous 'Kitab al-Fawa'id fi Usul 'Ilm al-Bahr wa 'l-Qawa'id' (The Book of Useful Information on the Principles and Rules of Navigation). His writings not only provided practical guidance for navigators but also contributed significantly to the understanding of geography and oceanography during his time.

0909IbnMabrid.bio: Ibn al-Mabrid, Ibn ʿAbd al-Hādī, was a distinguished scholar in the fields of hadith and fiqh. His expertise was not limited to Islamic jurisprudence; he also made significant contributions to Arabic literature and linguistics. Among his notable works, his commentaries on hadith collections stand out for their depth of analysis and clarity, serving as essential references for scholars. His writings on Arabic grammar and syntax are praised for their precision and insight, reflecting his mastery over the Arabic language.

0910IbnAbiJumhurAhsai.bio: Ibn Abi Jumhur Ahsai was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Al-Ahsa, who made significant contributions to the fields of philosophy, theology, and jurisprudence. He is best known for his efforts to reconcile the intellectual traditions of Avicennism and Illuminationism with Twelver Shi'a theology. Among his notable works is 'Awa'id al-Ayyam', a comprehensive treatise that delves into the intricacies of Shi'a doctrine and philosophy. His writings reflect a deep engagement with the metaphysical questions of his time, offering insights that bridged various strands of Islamic thought.

0910MuhammadIbnZahiraQurashi.bio: Muḥammad b. Ẓahīraŧ al-Qurašī, also known as Abū al-Ḫayr, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are noted for their depth and insight. He engaged deeply with the Quranic studies, Hadith, and the legal rulings of his time, making significant contributions to the understanding and interpretation of Islamic law. His works, characterized by their scholarly rigor and clarity, served as important references for both contemporaries and later scholars in the field of Islamic studies.

0911Samhudi.bio: Samhudi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and historian, renowned for his deep knowledge in Islamic jurisprudence and history. He is best known for his comprehensive work on the history and topography of Medina, which remains a crucial reference for scholars studying the Islamic period of the city. His meticulous documentation of Medina's landmarks, including the Prophet's Mosque, and his detailed accounts of the city's transformations over the centuries, have made his works invaluable. His scholarship reflects a profound commitment to preserving the Islamic heritage and offers insightful perspectives on the historical and religious significance of Medina.

0911Suyuti.bio: Jalal al-Din al-Suyuti was an Egyptian polymath whose expertise spanned various fields of Islamic learning, including hadith, fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence), tafsir (Quranic exegesis), and history. He authored numerous works, the most renowned being 'Al-Itqan fi Ulum al-Qur'an', a comprehensive study on the sciences of the Quran, and 'Tafsir al-Jalalayn', a widely acclaimed Quranic exegesis co-authored with Jalal al-Din al-Mahalli. His scholarly contributions also include 'Al-Durr al-Manthur', a significant compilation of hadiths related to Quranic commentary. Al-Suyuti's prolific writing and intellectual legacy have made him a revered figure in Islamic scholarship.

0912CaliIbnQasimZaqqaq.bio: Cali Ibn Qasim Zaqqaq, also known as Abu al-Hassan Ali ibn Qasim ibn Muhammad al-Tujibi, was a distinguished Andalusian poet and literary figure. His work primarily revolved around the genre of zajal, a form of vernacular poetry. Zaqqaq's poetry was celebrated for its eloquence and wit, often exploring themes of love, social commentary, and the human condition. His contributions to Andalusian literature were significant, making him a notable figure in the cultural and literary history of al-Andalus. His mastery of the zajal form has been praised by scholars and poets alike.

0914IbnYahyaWansharisi.bio: Ibn Yahya Wansharisi, a distinguished Maliki jurist, was renowned for his profound scholarship in Islamic jurisprudence. Originating from Tlemcen, his scholarly pursuits led him to author several influential works, among which his magnum opus, a comprehensive collection of Maliki fatwas, stands out for its depth and breadth. This compilation not only served as a pivotal reference for Maliki law but also underscored his meticulous approach to Islamic legal principles. His dedication to the Maliki school of thought significantly enriched the Islamic legal tradition, making his contributions invaluable to scholars and students alike.

0914SarimDinWaziri.bio: Sarim Din Waziri, a distinguished Islamic scholar, made significant contributions to the fields of Hadith and Islamic jurisprudence. His scholarly work is characterized by deep analysis and a commitment to the principles of Islamic law. Waziri's writings, which include comprehensive treatises on various aspects of Islamic theology and law, have been widely recognized for their depth of knowledge and clarity of argument. His dedication to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences has left a lasting mark on the scholarly community, making his works essential reading for students and scholars alike.

0916IbnFanad.bio: Ibn Fanad, formally known as Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Yunus al-Zahif al-Sa'di, also recognized by the honorific Badr al-Din, was a distinguished scholar in the fields of Hadith and Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic scholarship are marked by his rigorous analysis and interpretation of Islamic texts. Despite the challenges of his era, his works have been a reference point for scholars seeking to understand the complexities of Hadith and the nuances of Islamic law. His dedication to Islamic sciences has made his writings an invaluable asset for researchers and scholars alike.

0917CaliIbnMaymun.bio: Cali Ibn Maymun was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and philosophy were profound, with his works being considered essential readings in Islamic studies. He was known for his deep understanding of Sharia law and for his ability to interpret Islamic texts with great insight. His writings, which covered various aspects of Islamic law and ethics, served as a foundation for future generations of scholars. Despite the challenges of his time, his scholarly work remained influential, showcasing his dedication to the pursuit of knowledge.

0918BafadlHadrami.bio: Bafadl Hadrami was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the traditions and teachings of Islam. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and his interpretations of Islamic law have been influential. He was known for his profound understanding of the Quran and Hadith, which he meticulously studied and taught. His works, characterized by their depth and clarity, serve as significant references for scholars and students of Islam. His dedication to teaching and his scholarly works reflect his commitment to the dissemination of Islamic knowledge and principles.

0918IbnAscadJalalDinDawwani.bio: Jalal al-Din al-Dawwani was a Persian philosopher, theologian, and jurist who made significant contributions to Islamic philosophy and jurisprudence. He is best known for his work in reconciling the intellectual traditions of Avicennism and Illuminationism, thereby influencing the development of later Islamic thought. Among his notable works are 'Akhlaq-i Jalali' (Jalal's Ethics), which explores ethical and philosophical questions, and his commentaries on logic and Islamic law, which have been widely studied and referenced in Islamic scholarly circles.

0918IbnQasimShamsDinGhazzi.bio: Ibn Qasim Shams Din Ghazzi, also known as Ibn al-Gharabile, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and literature are well-regarded. He authored several works that have been influential in the study and practice of Islamic law. His writings reflect a deep understanding of the complexities of Islamic jurisprudence and offer insights into the legal and religious issues of his time. His scholarly work continues to be a reference for students and scholars of Islamic studies.

0919IbnGhaziMiknasi.bio: Ibn Ghazi Miknasi was a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence and history. He authored several influential works, including a comprehensive commentary on Malik's Muwatta, which has been celebrated for its depth of analysis and clarity in explaining the intricacies of Maliki jurisprudence. His contributions extend to the field of history, where his meticulous documentation of events and figures of his time offers valuable insights into the Islamic world. His writings not only served as educational resources but also as a bridge connecting future generations with the rich Islamic tradition.

0920IbnKhalilZaynDinMalati.bio: Ibn Khalil Zayn Din Malati was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist within the Hanafi school of thought. Originating from Malatya, he later moved to Cairo, where he significantly contributed to Islamic jurisprudence. His works are characterized by their depth in Hanafi fiqh, showcasing his profound understanding and interpretation of Islamic law. Among his notable contributions is his commentary on legal texts, which has been a valuable resource for scholars and students of Islamic jurisprudence. His scholarly efforts have made him a respected figure in the study of Islamic law.

0920IbnMahmudNakhjawani.bio: Ibn Mahmud Nakhjawani, known as Sheikh Alwan, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-regarded. He authored several influential works that delve into the intricacies of Islamic law and Sufism. His scholarly pursuits and writings have been instrumental in the dissemination of Islamic knowledge. His expertise in Islamic jurisprudence made him a revered figure among his contemporaries. His works continue to be studied for their depth and insight into Islamic teachings.

0921JibrailIbnQilaci.bio: Ibn al-Qilāʿī, also known as Jibrail Ibn Qilaci, was a distinguished historian and hadith scholar. His contributions to Islamic scholarship are vast, with his works encompassing the fields of history, hadith, and Islamic jurisprudence. Among his notable works is a comprehensive history of Aleppo, which remains a valuable resource for understanding the Islamic and cultural history of the region. His meticulous approach to the collection and authentication of hadiths has also been highly regarded, making him a respected figure in Islamic studies.

0922IbnShaykhTarabulusi.bio: Ibn Shaykh Tarabulusi, a Hanafi scholar, made significant contributions to Islamic jurisprudence. His works delve into the complexities of fiqh, offering insights and interpretations that have been studied by scholars and students alike. His dedication to understanding and explaining the nuances of Islamic law has made his writings a valuable resource for those seeking to deepen their knowledge of Hanafi jurisprudence. His scholarly efforts reflect a deep commitment to the principles of Islam, making his contributions a lasting part of the intellectual heritage of the Muslim world.

0923AhmadQastallani.bio: Al-Qastallani, known formally as Shihab al-Din Abu al-Abbas Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Abi Bakr ibn Abd al-Malik al-Khatib, al-Shafi'i, was a distinguished Islamic scholar and historian. He is renowned for his extensive works on the Hadith and Sirah, which are considered vital resources in Islamic studies. Among his notable contributions is a comprehensive commentary on Sahih al-Bukhari, which is highly regarded for its depth of analysis and insight into the Prophetic traditions. His scholarly efforts have made him a respected figure in the field of Islamic scholarship.

0923IbnCabdAllahKhazraji.bio: Ibn Cabd Allah Khazraji, also known as Safi al-Din Ahmad ibn Abd Allah al-Khazraji al-Ansari al-Sa'adi al-Yamani, was a distinguished historian and hadith scholar. He is best known for his work in the field of Islamic history, particularly for his contributions to the understanding of the early Islamic period. His meticulous approach to the collection and authentication of hadiths and historical events has been highly regarded. Among his notable works is the comprehensive history of the tribes of Arabia, which remains a crucial reference for scholars studying the Islamic and pre-Islamic eras.

0925IbnCabdWahhabAcraj.bio: Ibn Cabd Wahhab Acraj, known as Abu al-Fadl, was a distinguished scholar in the fields of Hadith and Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic scholarship are marked by his rigorous analysis and interpretation of Islamic texts. He was deeply engaged in the study of Hadith, dedicating his life to collecting, verifying, and commenting on the sayings and actions of the Prophet Muhammad. His works remain a significant resource for scholars and students of Islamic studies, reflecting his profound understanding of the complexities of Islamic law and tradition.

0926ZakariyyaAnsari.bio: Zakariyya Ansari was a distinguished scholar in the Shafi'i school of Islamic jurisprudence. He hailed from Egypt and was deeply immersed in the study and teaching of Islamic sciences. Ansari authored several influential works, notably in the fields of fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence), tafsir (Quranic exegesis), and hadith. His contributions include commentaries on the works of earlier scholars, which have been celebrated for their depth of insight and clarity. His writings continue to be studied and respected for their scholarly merit and contribution to Islamic legal thought.

0927Culaymi.bio: Culaymi, known in Arabic as العليمي, was a distinguished historian and scholar within the Hanbali school of Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to the field of Islamic history are notable, with his works often delving into the intricacies of historical events and figures from an Islamic perspective. Among his renowned works, his detailed accounts of the history and landmarks of Jerusalem stand out, providing valuable insights into the religious and cultural significance of the city. His scholarly efforts have made him a respected figure in the study of Islamic history.

0927Nucaymi.bio: ʿAbd al-Qādir b. Muḥammad al-Nuʿaymī al-Dimašqī was a distinguished historian and biographer from Damascus. He is best known for his work, 'Al-Dāris fī Tārīkh al-Madāris,' which is an invaluable resource for understanding the history of Islamic educational institutions in Damascus. His meticulous documentation of scholars, madrasas, and the educational landscape of his time provides a detailed glimpse into the intellectual and spiritual life of Damascus. His contributions are considered essential for scholars studying the Islamic and educational history of the region.

0927ShaykhCammiSacid.bio: Šayḫ ʿAmmī Saʿīd was a distinguished Islamic scholar and spiritual guide in the Maghreb region. He was deeply rooted in the Sufi tradition, focusing on the purification of the soul and the importance of inner spirituality. His teachings emphasized the significance of love and devotion to God, drawing from the rich Islamic spiritual heritage. Saʿīd's works contributed to the spread of Sufism in North Africa, where he was revered for his profound wisdom and insight into the mystical aspects of Islam. His approach to Sufism was characterized by a deep commitment to the spiritual journey towards God.

0928AbuCabbasShammakhi.bio: Al-Shammakhi, known formally as Abu al-Abbas Ahmad ibn Abi Uthman Sa'id ibn Abd al-Wahid al-Shammakhi al-Ifrani, was a distinguished historian and scholar from the Ifranid dynasty. He is renowned for his contributions to the field of Islamic history, particularly for his work on the history of scholars and notable figures in Islam. His meticulous documentation of the lives and achievements of Islamic scholars has been invaluable for researchers and historians. Al-Shammakhi's dedication to preserving the rich history of Islam through his writings has made him a respected figure in Islamic scholarship.

0928IbnQadiCajlun.bio: Ibn Qadi 'Ajlun, a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence, hailed from Damascus. He was deeply rooted in the Shafi'i school of thought. His contributions to Islamic scholarship are vast, with his expertise spanning hadith, fiqh, and history. Among his notable works, his biographical dictionary stands out, offering valuable insights into the lives of eminent scholars and figures of his time. His writings are characterized by meticulous research and a profound understanding of Islamic law, making him a respected authority in Islamic legal studies.

0928MujirDinCulaymi.bio: Mujir al-Din al-'Ulaymi, a distinguished historian and jurist from Jerusalem, made significant contributions to Islamic historiography. He is best known for his comprehensive work on the history and monuments of Jerusalem and Hebron, titled 'Al-Uns al-Jalil bi-Tarikh al-Quds wal-Khalil'. This work is celebrated for its detailed account of the religious, cultural, and architectural heritage of these cities, serving as an invaluable resource for scholars and historians. His expertise in Hanbali jurisprudence further solidified his reputation as a scholar deeply rooted in Islamic tradition and scholarship.

0928RabicIbnHabibFarahidi.bio: Rabic Ibn Habib Farahidi was a distinguished scholar in the field of Islamic studies. He dedicated his life to the interpretation and teaching of Islamic texts, contributing significantly to the understanding of the Quran and Hadith. His works are considered foundational in the study of Islamic jurisprudence and ethics. Farahidi's scholarly approach combined rigorous analysis with a deep respect for the traditions, making his contributions invaluable to scholars and students alike. His teachings continue to be a source of inspiration and guidance for those seeking to deepen their understanding of Islamic principles.

0929IbnKayyal.bio: Ibn Kayyāl, formally known as Abū al-Barakāt Muḥammad b. Aḥmad, was a distinguished scholar in the field of Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to the understanding and interpretation of Islamic law have been influential among scholars and students alike. He dedicated his life to studying, teaching, and writing about the complexities of Sharia, producing several works that have been referenced and studied in Islamic academic circles for centuries. His expertise in fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) made him a respected authority among his contemporaries and later generations.

0929MuhammadShaqrunWahrani.bio: Muhammad Shaqrun Wahrani was an Islamic scholar who dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences. He is best known for his contributions to the fields of Hadith and Fiqh, where his analytical approach and depth of understanding were widely recognized. His works often served as reference points for scholars and students alike, reflecting a profound grasp of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. Wahrani's teachings and writings continue to be studied for their insightful interpretations and scholarly precision.

0930IbnCumarBahraqHadrami.bio: Ibn Cumar Bahraq Hadrami, also known as Bahraq al-Yamani, was a distinguished scholar in the Shafi'i school of Islamic jurisprudence. Originating from Hadramawt, he was deeply versed in Islamic law, theology, and philosophy. His contributions to Islamic scholarship are marked by his profound understanding and interpretation of Shari'a. Bahraq Hadrami's works reflect a meticulous approach to Islamic jurisprudence, blending traditional insights with practical applications. His writings, though not extensively detailed here, continue to be studied for their depth and clarity in understanding Islamic legal principles.

0930IbnIyas.bio: Ibn Iyas, formally known as Muhammad ibn Ahmad, was an Egyptian historian renowned for his detailed chronicle of Egypt, particularly during the Mamluk and early Ottoman periods. His most celebrated work, 'Bada'i' al-Zuhur fi Waqa'i' al-Duhur', is a vital source for understanding the social, political, and economic aspects of Egypt from the late 15th century into the early 16th century. This comprehensive history offers insights into the daily life, architecture, and significant events of the time, making it an indispensable resource for scholars of Middle Eastern history.

0936IbnAhmadShammacHalabi.bio: Ibn Ahmad Shammac Halabi was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Aleppo. He dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences, contributing significantly to the fields of Hadith and Fiqh. His scholarly works are characterized by their depth of knowledge and clarity, making them valuable resources for students and scholars alike. Among his contributions, his commentaries and interpretations of Islamic texts stand out for their insight and scholarly rigor. His dedication to Islamic scholarship has made his works a lasting part of Islamic academic study.

0938IbnCaliBalawi.bio: Al-Balawī, also known as Abū Ja'far Aḥmad ibn 'Alī al-Balawī al-Wādī āshī, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and literature are well-regarded. His works, which delve into the intricacies of Islamic law and theology, have been studied by scholars and students alike for their depth and insight. Al-Balawī's writings continue to be a reference for those seeking to understand the complexities of Islamic legal and theological principles.

0938IbnQasimSirajDinNashshar.bio: Ibn Qasim Siraj Din Nashshar, a distinguished Egyptian scholar in the Shafi'i school of Islamic jurisprudence, made significant contributions to Islamic legal thought and literature. His works, deeply rooted in the Shafi'i methodology, offer insights into the intricacies of Islamic law and its application. His scholarly output reflects a profound engagement with the legal and religious texts of his time, making him a respected figure among his contemporaries and later generations of Islamic scholars. His dedication to the Shafi'i madhhab is evident in his meticulous analysis and interpretation of Islamic legal principles.

0940IbnHusaynMuhaqqiqThaniKaraki.bio: Ibn Husayn Muhaqqiq Thani Karaki, also known as Al-Muhaqqiq Al-Karaki, was a distinguished Islamic jurist and scholar. He made significant contributions to Shia Islamic thought, particularly in the fields of jurisprudence and theology. His works, which include comprehensive treatises on Islamic law and ethics, have been influential in shaping the discourse within Shia Islam. Among his notable works is a commentary on 'Lum'a al-Dimashqiyya,' a key text in Shia jurisprudence. His scholarly efforts were focused on elucidating complex legal and theological issues, aiming to provide clear guidance based on the principles of Shia Islam.

0940IbnKamalBasha.bio: Ibn Kamal Basha was a distinguished Ottoman scholar and jurist. He made significant contributions to Islamic jurisprudence, theology, and philosophy. His works often integrated the rich traditions of Islamic scholarship with the evolving needs of his time, reflecting a deep engagement with both the classical texts and contemporary issues. Among his notable contributions is his commentary on Sahih al-Bukhari, which remains a valuable resource for scholars and students of Islamic studies. His writings continue to be studied for their insightful analysis and scholarly depth.

0940IbnQasimMuhyiDinAmasi.bio: Ibn Qasim Muhyi Din Amasi was a distinguished Hanafi scholar, deeply rooted in Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His scholarly contributions are vast, with a particular focus on the interpretation and application of Hanafi law. He was renowned for his profound understanding of Islamic legal principles and their practical implications in society. His works serve as a cornerstone for students and scholars of Islamic law, offering insights into the complexities of jurisprudence and its application through a Hanafi lens. His dedication to Islamic scholarship has made his writings a valuable resource for generations.

0940IbnSulaymanIbnKamalBasha.bio: Ibn Sulayman Ibn Kamal Basha, also known as Shams al-Din, was a distinguished Ottoman scholar and jurist. He served as Sheikh al-Islam, the highest religious authority in the Ottoman Empire, showcasing his profound influence in Islamic jurisprudence. His scholarly contributions include a wide range of subjects, notably in the fields of Hanafi fiqh, Quranic exegesis, and history. Among his notable works is a commentary on Sahih al-Bukhari, which remains a significant reference for Islamic scholars. His writings reflect a blend of traditional Islamic scholarship with the intellectual currents of his time.

0942IbnYusufShami.bio: Ibn Yusuf Shami, formally known as Muhammad ibn Yusuf al-Salihi al-Shami, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. He is renowned for his contributions to the Hadith sciences, particularly through his meticulous documentation and analysis of Prophetic traditions. Among his notable works, 'Subul al-Huda wa al-Rashad fi Sirah Khayr al-Ibad' stands out, offering a comprehensive biography of the Prophet Muhammad. This work is celebrated for its depth and accuracy, drawing from a wide array of sources to present a detailed account of the Prophet's life and teachings.

0942KhalilTatai.bio: Khalil Tatai was a distinguished Maliki jurist known for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence. His expertise in the Maliki school of thought was unparalleled, making him a revered figure among scholars and students alike. He authored several influential works that continue to be studied and referenced in the fields of Islamic law and theology. His writings are celebrated for their clarity, depth, and comprehensive coverage of Maliki jurisprudence, solidifying his status as a pivotal figure in the development of Islamic legal thought.

0943CisamDinIsfarayini.bio: Cisam Din Isfarayini, originally named إبراهيم بن محمد بن عربشاه عصام الدين الحنفي, was a distinguished Islamic scholar within the Hanafi school of thought. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-regarded, with his works serving as reference points for scholars and students alike. His expertise in fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) and his ability to interpret Islamic law in a manner that was both profound and accessible made him a revered figure among his contemporaries. His writings continue to be studied for their depth of knowledge and insight into the Hanafi tradition.

0944IbnCaliIbnDaybacShaybani.bio: Ibn Cali Ibn Daybac Shaybani was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and literature are well-regarded among scholars and students of Islamic studies. He authored several works that delve into the intricacies of Islamic law, ethics, and theology. His writings are characterized by their depth of knowledge and clarity, making them essential readings for those interested in the Islamic legal tradition and its application through the centuries.

0944IbnDaybac.bio: Ibn al-Daybaʿ al-Shaybani, formally known as Wajih al-Din ʿAbd al-Rahman ibn ʿAli al-Shaybani, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic tradition. He made significant contributions to the fields of history, literature, and Islamic jurisprudence. His works, deeply rooted in the Shafi'i school of thought, reflect a profound understanding of Islamic law and ethics. Among his notable contributions is a comprehensive encyclopedia of Yemeni history and biographies, which serves as a crucial resource for scholars studying the region's Islamic and cultural heritage.

0945ShamsDinDawudi.bio: Al-Dāwūdī, formally known as Shams al-Dīn Muḥammad b. ʿAlī b. Aḥmad al-Dāwūdī al-Mālikī, was a distinguished scholar in the Maliki school of Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic legal thought and jurisprudence are well-documented through his extensive writings. Among his works, his commentaries and interpretations of Maliki law stand out for their depth and clarity, serving as essential references for scholars and students of Islamic law. His scholarly efforts were dedicated to elucidating complex legal issues, making significant strides in the understanding and application of Maliki jurisprudence.

0947BamakhramaHimyari.bio: Bamakhrama Himyari was a distinguished historian and scholar from the Himyarite region. He was deeply versed in Islamic jurisprudence, adhering to the Shafi'i school of thought. His contributions to the field of history are notable, with a focus on the genealogies and histories of Arab tribes, particularly those from the Himyarite lineage. His works are characterized by meticulous research and a commitment to preserving the narratives of the past. His scholarly efforts provided a foundation for future historians in understanding the complex social and political landscapes of the Arab world.

0948MuhammadIbnKhidrRumi.bio: Muhammad Ibn Khidr Rumi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist within the Hanafi school of thought. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology were profound, with his works being studied and revered by scholars and students alike. He was particularly known for his deep understanding of Islamic law and his ability to interpret and apply it to the complexities of daily life. His writings continue to be a source of guidance and inspiration for those seeking to deepen their understanding of Islamic principles and practices.

0950Anonymous.bio: This anonymous author is recognized for compiling a significant work on the Abbasid Caliphate, detailing its political, social, and cultural aspects. Despite the lack of personal details, the author's contribution provides a crucial insight into the Abbasid era, offering a comprehensive overview of its administration, notable figures, and historical events. The work stands as a vital source for researchers and historians, shedding light on the complexities and dynamics of one of the most influential periods in Islamic history.

0950IbnSabat.bio: Ibn Sabat was a notable scholar whose contributions to Islamic literature and thought have been acknowledged by his contemporaries and later scholars. His works, which span various aspects of the Islamic sciences, have been studied and referenced extensively. Despite the challenges of his time, he managed to produce a significant body of work that continues to be of interest to scholars and students of Islamic studies. His writings not only reflect the intellectual climate of his era but also offer insights into the religious and philosophical discussions that were prevalent.

0950IbnSulaymanFadilQatifi.bio: Ibn Sulayman Fadil Qatifi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and philosopher. His contributions to Islamic thought are marked by his deep engagement with philosophical and theological questions. He authored several works that explore the intricacies of Islamic jurisprudence and ethics. His writings reflect a keen intellect and a profound understanding of the Islamic tradition, making him a respected figure among his contemporaries. His scholarly pursuits were not limited to a single discipline, as he ventured into various fields of knowledge, demonstrating versatility and depth in his intellectual endeavors.

0950MuhyiDinShaykhZada.bio: Muhyi Din Shaykh Zada was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist within the Hanafi school of thought. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence are well-regarded, with his works serving as essential references for scholars and students alike. Among his notable works is a comprehensive commentary on 'Al-Hidayah', a key text in Hanafi jurisprudence. This commentary not only elucidates complex legal principles but also integrates the Hanafi doctrine with insights from other Islamic schools of thought, showcasing his profound understanding and respect for the diversity within Islamic jurisprudence.

0950ShaykhZadah.bio: Shaykh Zadah, formally known as Muhammad ibn Mustafa al-Qawjawi, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-regarded among scholars and students of Islamic studies. Shaykh Zadah's works delve into the intricacies of Islamic law, offering insights and interpretations that have been influential in the development of Islamic legal thought. His writings continue to be a subject of study and reference for those seeking to understand the complexities of Islamic jurisprudence and its application in various contexts.

0953Akhdari.bio: Akhdari was a renowned scholar in the Maliki school of Islamic jurisprudence. He is best known for his work on Islamic legal theory, particularly his concise text on Maliki fiqh, which has been a foundational educational resource in North Africa. His writings emphasize the importance of purification, prayer, and the performance of religious duties, aiming to provide a comprehensive guide for Muslims seeking to understand and apply Maliki law in their daily lives. His contributions have been instrumental in the education of countless scholars and students in Islamic jurisprudence.

0953IbnTulun.bio: Ibn Tulun, a distinguished scholar from Damascus, was deeply rooted in the Hanafi school of thought. His scholarly pursuits were vast, covering various fields of Islamic studies. He was renowned for his contributions to Hadith, where his critical approach to the authentication and compilation of narrations set him apart. His works are characterized by meticulous research and a profound understanding of Islamic jurisprudence, making him a respected figure among his contemporaries. His writings continue to be a valuable resource for scholars and students of Islamic studies.

0954HattabRucayniMaghribi.bio: Hattab Rucayni Maghribi, also known as Shams al-Din Abu Abd Allah Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Tarabulusi al-Maghribi, was a distinguished Maliki jurist. He is renowned for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence, particularly within the Maliki school of thought. His works, which include extensive commentaries and interpretations of Maliki law, have been pivotal in the study and application of Islamic legal principles. His scholarly efforts have solidified his status as a respected authority in Islamic legal studies, making his writings essential reading for scholars and students alike.

0955MuhammadKarakiHairi.bio: Muhammad Karaki Hairi was a distinguished Islamic jurist and theologian. He is renowned for his profound contributions to Shia Islamic thought and jurisprudence.
