His scholarly works, deeply rooted in Islamic tradition, have been instrumental in shaping the theological discourse within Shia Islam. Among his notable works, his comprehensive treatises on Islamic law and ethics stand out for their depth and insight. His writings continue to be a vital source of knowledge and inspiration for scholars and students of Islamic studies.

0956IbnCumarShamsDinSafiri.bio: Ibn Cumar Shams Din Safiri was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist within the Shafi'i school of thought. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and his scholarly works have been recognized for their depth and insight. He dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences, producing several notable works that have been referenced by scholars for centuries. His writings cover a broad spectrum of Islamic jurisprudence, showcasing his profound understanding of the Shafi'i madhhab and his commitment to the dissemination of Islamic knowledge.

0956IbnMuhammadHalabiHanafi.bio: Ibn Muhammad Halabi Hanafi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist within the Hanafi school of thought. He is best known for his comprehensive work on Islamic jurisprudence, which served as a pivotal reference for scholars and students alike. His writings are characterized by their clarity, depth, and meticulous adherence to the principles of Hanafi jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic legal theory and practice have been celebrated for their scholarly rigor and practical applicability, making him a revered figure among scholars of Islamic law.

0957MuhammadIbnYahyaBahranZaydi.bio: Muhammad Ibn Yahya Bahran Zaydi, originally from Basra with lineage tracing back to Tamim, was a distinguished scholar whose contributions spanned various Islamic sciences. His works, deeply rooted in the traditions and teachings of Islam, reflect a profound understanding and interpretation of religious texts. Residing and passing away in Sa'dah, his scholarly pursuits left a significant mark on the study and practice of Islam, particularly through his writings which continue to be referenced for their depth and insight into the complexities of Islamic jurisprudence and theology.

0957ShihabDinRamli.bio: Shihab al-Din Ahmad ibn Hamza al-Ansari al-Ramli al-Shafi'i, known as Shihab al-Din al-Ramli, was a distinguished Islamic jurist within the Shafi'i school of thought. His scholarly contributions are highly regarded in Islamic jurisprudence, particularly for his expertise in fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence). Among his notable works is the extensive legal manual that serves as a key reference for Shafi'i jurists and students of Islamic law. His writings continue to be studied and respected for their depth of knowledge and clarity in the principles of Shafi'i jurisprudence.

0961HasanWazzan.bio: Hasan Wazzan, known in the West as Leo Africanus, was a Moroccan explorer and writer. He is most famous for his detailed book, 'Description of Africa,' which provided Europe with its first comprehensive view of the geography, peoples, and cultures of the African continent. Captured by Christian pirates and presented to Pope Leo X, he converted to Christianity and took on a new name. His works, written in Italian, played a significant role in shaping European perceptions of Africa for centuries.

0961SulaymanMahri.bio: Sulaymān al-Mahrī was an esteemed astronomer and mathematician, renowned for his contributions to the fields of geography and navigation. His works, deeply rooted in the rich tradition of Islamic science, provided significant advancements in navigational techniques and geographical knowledge. Among his notable contributions is a comprehensive treatise on the use of the astrolabe, a vital tool for astronomers and navigators alike. His expertise also extended to the development of navigational charts that were crucial for the voyages of the time. Al-Mahrī's work in compiling and correcting geographical data further solidified his reputation as a leading scholar in his field.

0963CabdRahmanAbuFathCabbasi.bio: Cabd Rahman Abu Fath Cabbasi was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the rich tapestry of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His scholarly contributions spanned various aspects of Islamic studies, making him a revered figure among his contemporaries. His works, characterized by profound insights and a meticulous approach to Islamic law and ethics, served as significant references for both his peers and subsequent generations of scholars. His dedication to the dissemination and interpretation of Islamic teachings underscored his life's work, reflecting his profound commitment to his faith and its scholarly tradition.

0963IbnMuhammadIbnCiraqKanani.bio: Ibn Muhammad Ibn Ciraq Kanani was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the traditions of Hadith studies. His scholarly pursuits led him to author 'Tanzih al-Shari'ah', a monumental work that meticulously addresses the authenticity of various Hadiths, distinguishing the genuine from the spurious. His dedication to Islamic jurisprudence and the principles of Hadith verification significantly contributed to the field, making his works a valuable resource for scholars and students alike. His expertise in Islamic law and tradition showcases the depth of his knowledge and his commitment to preserving Islamic teachings.

0964CabdCazizMiknasi.bio: Cabd Caziz Miknasi was a Moroccan scholar and historian, renowned for his contributions to the field of Islamic history. He is best known for his detailed chronicles of North African history, focusing particularly on the Maghreb region. His works are celebrated for their meticulous research and the depth of historical insight they provide, offering a comprehensive view of the political, social, and cultural dynamics of his time. Miknasi's writings remain a valuable resource for scholars and historians, providing a window into the rich historical tapestry of North Africa.

0965ShahidThani.bio: Shahid Thani, originally named Zain al-Din bin Ali al-Amili, was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Jabal Amel. He is renowned for his profound contributions to Shi'a jurisprudence and his efforts in teaching and writing. Among his notable works, 'Rawdat al-Jannat' stands out as a significant contribution to Islamic legal studies. His scholarly pursuits extended to various fields, including ethics and theology, making him a revered figure in Islamic scholarship. His dedication to education and the Islamic community has left a lasting mark on the Shi'a intellectual tradition.

0965SharafDinAstarabadiHusayni.bio: Sharaf Din Astarabadi Husayni was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist. He dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic jurisprudence and principles. His profound understanding of Islamic law led him to author several influential texts that are still referenced by scholars and students of Islam today. His works are celebrated for their depth, clarity, and insightful analysis of complex religious matters. Sharaf Din's contributions to Islamic scholarship have made him a respected figure among academics and religious scholars alike.

0965ZaynDinCabdGhaffar.bio: Zayn Din Cabd Ghaffar was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply immersed in the study and teaching of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His contributions to Islamic literature include extensive writings on the principles of fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) and the interpretation of the Quran. His works are characterized by a profound understanding of the intricacies of Islamic law and its application to the daily lives of Muslims. His teachings and writings continue to be a source of guidance and inspiration for scholars and students of Islam.

0966HusaynDiyarbakri.bio: Husayn Diyarbakri was a distinguished Islamic scholar and historian. He is best known for his comprehensive works on Islamic history and jurisprudence. Among his notable contributions is 'Tarikh al-Khamis', a detailed chronicle of Islamic history from the time of the Prophet Muhammad until his own era. This work is highly regarded for its meticulous research and insightful analysis. Diyarbakri's expertise also extended to Islamic law, where he made significant contributions to the understanding and interpretation of Sharia. His scholarly works continue to be studied and respected for their depth and accuracy.

0966ShahidThani.bio: Shahid Thani, originally known as Zain al-Din bin Nur al-Din al-Amili, was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Jabal Amel, in present-day Lebanon. He is renowned for his profound contributions to Shi'a Islamic jurisprudence and his efforts in teaching and writing. Among his notable works are 'Sharh al-Lum'a,' an extensive commentary on 'Al-Lum'a al-Dimashqiyya,' and 'Masalik al-Afham,' which further elucidates Shi'a legal principles. His scholarly pursuits led him to reside in various Islamic intellectual centers, including Damascus and Aleppo, where he engaged deeply with Islamic law and ethics.

0968IbnAhmadAbuNajaHajjawi.bio: Musa ibn Ahmad Abu Naja Hajjawi, a distinguished Islamic jurist, made significant contributions to Hanbali jurisprudence. Originating from Jerusalem, he later moved to Salahiyya, marking a pivotal shift in his scholarly pursuits. His most celebrated work, 'Zad al-Mustaqni', is a concise yet comprehensive manual of Hanbali law, serving as a cornerstone for students and scholars alike. This text, revered for its clarity and depth, distills complex legal principles, making them accessible to a broader audience. Hajjawi's scholarly rigor and dedication to Islamic law have cemented his status as a revered figure in Islamic legal studies.

0968Tashkuprizadah.bio: Ṭāškuprī Zādah was a distinguished Ottoman historian and scholar. He is renowned for his comprehensive works on the history of the Ottoman Empire, which have been invaluable for scholars studying the period. His meticulous documentation of events, figures, and the socio-political landscape of his time provides a detailed account of the Ottoman era. Among his notable works, his chronicles stand out for their depth of detail and historical accuracy, making him a respected figure in the field of Islamic and Ottoman history.

0970IbnIbrahimIbnNujaymMisri.bio: Ibn Nujaym Misri, formally known as Zain ad-Din Ibn Ibrahim Ibn Muhammad, was a distinguished scholar in the Hanafi school of Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic legal theory and practice are monumental, with his work 'Al-Bahr al-Raiq' being among the most celebrated. This comprehensive encyclopedia of Hanafi jurisprudence has served as a cornerstone for legal scholars and students alike. His expertise not only covered Islamic law but also extended to the intricacies of legal methodology, making his writings essential for understanding the application of Islamic principles in legal matters.

0971IbnIbrahimIbnHanbaliHalabi.bio: Ibn Ibrahim Ibn Hanbali Halabi, a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence, made significant contributions to the Hanafi school of thought. His expertise in fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) was widely recognized, and he authored several influential works that continue to be studied. Among his notable contributions is his commentary on legal texts, which has served as a critical resource for scholars and students of Islamic law. His writings reflect a deep understanding of the complexities of Islamic jurisprudence and offer insightful analyses on various legal issues.

0972IbnAhmadFakihi.bio: Ibn Ahmad Fakihi was a distinguished historian and scholar from Mecca. His writings not only delve into the intricacies of Islamic law but also explore the historical context of its development, offering a comprehensive understanding of the subject.

1025IbnQadiMaknasi.bio: Ibn Qadi Maknasi, formally known as Abu al-Abbas Ahmad ibn Muhammad al-Maknasi, was a distinguished historian and scholar from Meknes. His contributions to the field of history and his scholarly works have been recognized for their depth and accuracy. He meticulously documented the events and figures of his time, providing future generations with a valuable resource for understanding the historical context of the period. His writings remain a testament to his dedication to preserving the history of his region.

1029IbnMuhammadMansurBiLlah.bio: Ibn Muhammad Mansur Bi Llah, known as Al-Mansur Bi Llah Al-Qasim, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-documented in several of his works. He was particularly renowned for his deep understanding of Islamic law and its application. His scholarly pursuits were not limited to jurisprudence; he also made significant contributions to the fields of hadith and Islamic philosophy. His writings continue to be a reference for scholars and students of Islamic studies.

1029QasimIbnMuhammadImam.bio: Qasim Ibn Muhammad was a revered Islamic scholar and jurist, deeply rooted in the rich tradition of Islamic jurisprudence. He was known for his profound understanding of the Quran and Hadith, which allowed him to contribute significantly to the development of Islamic law. His works and teachings have been influential in shaping the principles and practices of Islamic jurisprudence. His dedication to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences made him a respected figure among his contemporaries and later generations of scholars.

1030IbnGhanimBaghdadiHanafi.bio: Ibn Ghanim Baghdadi Hanafi was a distinguished scholar in the Hanafi school of Islamic jurisprudence. Residing in Baghdad, he contributed significantly to the legal discourse of his time. His works are characterized by a deep understanding of Hanafi principles, and he was known for his ability to articulate complex legal issues in a clear and accessible manner. His scholarly efforts were dedicated to elucidating and expanding upon the teachings of the Hanafi madhhab, making his writings valuable resources for students and scholars of Islamic law.

1031BahaDinCamili.bio: Baha Din Camili, known as البهائي العاملي in Arabic, was a multifaceted scholar whose contributions spanned various fields including jurisprudence, mathematics, astronomy, and architecture. He is renowned for his work in the development of the science of mechanics in the Islamic world and for his architectural contributions, notably the design of the Sheikh Lotfollah Mosque in Isfahan. His scholarly works, which include treatises on fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) and philosophy, reflect his profound knowledge and versatility. Among his notable works is the 'Kashkul', which encompasses a wide range of subjects from anecdotes to serious theological discussions.

1031CabdRaufMunawi.bio: Cabd Rauf Munawi was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the traditions of hadith and Sufism. His scholarly contributions span a wide range of Islamic disciplines, but he is most celebrated for his works in hadith studies and Sufi literature. Among his notable works are the Fayd al-Qadir, a comprehensive commentary on the Al-Jami' al-Saghir by Jalaluddin al-Suyuti, and the Kunuz al-Haqa'iq, which is revered in Sufi circles for its insightful exposition on spiritual truths and practices. His writings continue to be a vital source of knowledge and inspiration for scholars and practitioners alike.

1033MarciKarmi.bio: Marci Karmi was a distinguished scholar in the Hanbali school of Islamic jurisprudence. He hailed from Jerusalem and was deeply rooted in Islamic scholarship, contributing significantly to the fields of Fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) and Hadith. His works are considered essential readings for students and scholars alike, reflecting his profound understanding of Islamic law and tradition. Among his notable contributions is a comprehensive commentary on the 'Mukhtasar al-Khiraqi,' a key text in Hanbali jurisprudence, showcasing his expertise and depth of knowledge in Islamic legal matters.

1034AhmadSirhindi.bio: Ahmad Sirhindi, known for his profound spiritual and religious contributions, was a significant Islamic scholar and a Sufi of the Naqshbandi order. His teachings emphasized the importance of Sharia and the Sunnah, advocating for a balance between Sufism and Islamic law. Sirhindi's extensive writings, particularly his letters compiled in the 'Maktubat', address a wide range of spiritual and social issues, offering guidance to both rulers and the common people. His critique of certain Sufi practices aimed to purify the spiritual path and align it more closely with orthodox Islam.

1035AbuBakrAhdal.bio: Abu Bakr Ahdal was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic world, renowned for his profound knowledge and contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His scholarly works, deeply rooted in the principles of the Shafi'i school of thought, have been instrumental in guiding generations. Ahdal's writings, characterized by their depth and clarity, cover a wide range of subjects, including legal theory, ethics, and spiritual guidance. His dedication to teaching and his scholarly output have made him a revered figure among students and scholars of Islamic studies.

1035DawudIbnHadi.bio: Dāwūd b. al-Hādī was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the rich tradition of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His scholarly contributions spanned various aspects of Islamic studies, including Hadith, Fiqh, and the principles of Islamic jurisprudence. He was renowned for his profound understanding and interpretation of Islamic texts, which earned him a respected place among his contemporaries and later scholars. His works continue to be studied and referenced for their depth of knowledge and insight into the Islamic tradition.

1036AhmadBaba.bio: Ahmad Baba, a distinguished scholar from Timbuktu, is renowned for his profound knowledge in Islamic jurisprudence and his extensive writings. He was a prolific author, penning numerous works that have been highly regarded in the Islamic world. Among his notable contributions is the 'Nayl al-Ibtihaj bi Tatriz al-Dibaj,' a biographical dictionary that remains a valuable resource for scholars. His expertise was not limited to jurisprudence; he also made significant contributions to literature and history, demonstrating his versatility and depth of knowledge. His works continue to be studied and respected for their scholarly merit.

1038CabdQadirCaydarus.bio: Cabd Qadir Caydarus was a distinguished Islamic scholar and Sufi mystic. He hailed from the Al-Aydarus family, known for their deep spiritual and scholarly contributions to the Islamic world. His works, deeply rooted in Sufi teachings and Islamic jurisprudence, continue to be studied for their profound insights into spirituality and law. His dedication to the spiritual path and his scholarly pursuits made him a revered figure among his contemporaries in the Islamic scholarly community.

1039IbnLuqman.bio: Ibn Luqman, known as Shams al-Din Ahmad ibn Muhammad, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, theology, and philosophy. He authored several influential works that have been studied by scholars for centuries. His writings are characterized by their depth, clarity, and comprehensive coverage of the subjects he tackled. Despite the challenges of his time, Ibn Luqman's scholarly pursuits and dedication to Islamic education left a lasting mark on the intellectual landscape of the Islamic world.

1040CazmiZadah.bio: Cazmi Zadah was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic world, known for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His works, deeply rooted in the classical traditions of Islamic scholarship, provided insightful analyses and interpretations that enriched the intellectual and spiritual life of his contemporaries. His mastery of Islamic law and his ability to engage with complex theological issues with clarity and depth made his writings essential reading for scholars and students alike. His dedication to the pursuit of knowledge and understanding of the divine law left a lasting mark on the field of Islamic studies.

1041BurhanDinMaliki.bio: Burhan Din Maliki was a distinguished Maliki jurist and theologian. He is best known for his comprehensive work in Islamic jurisprudence and theology, which has been a significant reference for scholars in the Maliki school of thought. His contributions include detailed analyses and interpretations of Islamic legal principles, which have been influential in the development of Maliki jurisprudence. His works are characterized by their depth of knowledge and clarity, making them essential readings for students and scholars of Islamic law and theology.

1041Maqqari.bio: Al-Maqqarī, a historian and biographer, is renowned for his detailed chronicles of Islamic Spain and North Africa. His most celebrated work, 'Nafḥ al-ṭīb min ghuṣn al-Andalus al-raṭīb,' compiles an extensive history and the cultural achievements of Muslim Spain. Through his writings, al-Maqqarī preserved the intellectual and cultural heritage of Al-Andalus, offering invaluable insights into its society, literature, and scholars. His meticulous research and compilation of historical texts have made him a pivotal figure in Islamic historiography, particularly concerning the history of Al-Andalus and the Maghreb.

1041MirDamad.bio: Al-Dāmād, also known as Mir Damad, was a pivotal figure in the development of Islamic philosophy, particularly within the School of Isfahan. He is best known for his contributions to the philosophical system known as the 'School of Illumination,' where he sought to harmonize the intellectual traditions of Avicenna and Suhrawardi. His works, including 'Kitab al-Qabasat,' which explores the nature of existence and knowledge, have been influential in the discourse of metaphysics and epistemology within Islamic thought. His teachings and writings continue to be studied for their deep philosophical insights.

1044IbnBurhanDinHalabi.bio: Ibn Burhan Din Halabi, known as Nur al-Din al-Halabi, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. He authored several influential works, among which the most celebrated is 'Al-Sira al-Halabiyya,' a comprehensive biography of the Prophet Muhammad. This work is renowned for its meticulous research and depth of detail, drawing from a wide array of sources to present a vivid account of the Prophet's life and times. Al-Halabi's contributions to Islamic scholarship are marked by his dedication to accuracy and his profound respect for Islamic tradition.

1050IbnMansurBiLlahYamani.bio: Ibn Mansur Bi Llah Yamani, formally known as Al-Husayn ibn Al-Mansur Bi Llah Al-Qasim ibn Muhammad ibn Ali Al-Yamani, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic world. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, theology, and history. He was renowned for his deep understanding of Islamic law and his ability to interpret complex religious texts. His works, which include comprehensive treatises on Islamic jurisprudence and theology, have been studied by scholars and students of Islam for centuries. His scholarly approach combined rigorous analysis with a profound respect for the traditions of Islam.

1050IbnQasimHajari.bio: Ibn Qasim Hajari, originally named أحمد بن قاسم الحجري أفوقاي, was a distinguished historian and scholar. His contributions to the field of history and his scholarly works have been recognized for their depth and accuracy. Among his notable works, his travel writings stand out, providing insightful observations and detailed accounts of the places he visited. His meticulous approach to documenting his travels has made his work a valuable resource for researchers and historians alike, offering a unique perspective on the geographical and cultural landscapes of his time.

1050SadrDinShirazi.bio: Sadr Din Shirazi, also known as Sadr al-Muta'allihin, was a Persian philosopher, theologian, and mystic who made significant contributions to Islamic philosophy. He is best known for his works in the fields of philosophy, theology, and mysticism, including his magnum opus, 'Asfar al-Arba'a,' which is a comprehensive exposition of his philosophical thoughts. Shirazi's intellectual endeavors also extended to the realms of metaphysics and existentialism, where he sought to harmonize the teachings of Islam with philosophical inquiry. His writings continue to be studied for their profound insights into the nature of reality and the human experience.

1051Cimadi.bio: عبد الرحمن بن عماد الدين محمد بن محمد العمادي الدمشقي, known as Cimadi, was a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence and history. He hailed from Damascus and was deeply rooted in the Hanafi school of thought. Cimadi dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences, contributing significantly to the fields of fiqh and history through his writings. His works are characterized by their depth of knowledge and clarity, making them valuable resources for scholars and students alike. Cimadi's scholarly pursuits were driven by a profound commitment to his faith and an unwavering dedication to education.

1051IbnYunusBuhutiHanbali.bio: Ibn Yunus Buhuti Hanbali was a distinguished scholar in the Hanbali school of Islamic jurisprudence. He authored several influential works that contributed significantly to the Hanbali legal tradition. Among his notable contributions is the comprehensive legal manual that serves as a key reference for scholars and students of the Hanbali madhhab. His writings are characterized by their depth of analysis and clarity, making complex legal issues accessible to a broader audience. His dedication to the Hanbali school has left a lasting mark on Islamic legal scholarship.

1052CabdHaqqDihlawi.bio: Cabd Haqq Dihlawi was a distinguished Islamic scholar who made significant contributions to the study and interpretation of Hadith. He hailed from Delhi, a major center of Islamic learning in India. His works are considered crucial in the field of Islamic jurisprudence, particularly within the Hanafi school of thought. Among his notable contributions is the detailed commentary on Mishkat al-Masabih, a comprehensive collection of Hadith. His scholarly efforts were dedicated to preserving and elucidating the teachings of Islam, making him a revered figure among scholars and students of Islamic studies.

1055AhmadSharafi.bio: Šams al-Dīn al-Šarafī, also known as Ahmad Sharafi, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic world. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, theology, and Sufism. Al-Šarafī authored several influential works that are still referenced by scholars and students alike. His writings not only enriched Islamic scholarship but also provided a comprehensive understanding of the intricacies of Islamic law and spirituality. His dedication to teaching and writing made him a revered figure among his contemporaries and in Islamic educational circles.

1057IbnCallan.bio: Ibn Callan was a distinguished scholar in the Shafi'i school of Islamic jurisprudence. He was deeply rooted in the Ash'ari theological tradition and hailed from the Bakri family lineage, which traced its ancestry back to Abu Bakr al-Siddiq. His scholarly contributions spanned various Islamic sciences, but he is most renowned for his works in hadith and fiqh. Among his notable works is a comprehensive commentary on 'Riyad al-Salihin,' which has been celebrated for its insightful analysis and depth, making it a valuable resource for scholars and students alike.

1060IbnQaysar.bio: Ibn Qayṣar, formally known as ʿAbd Allāh b. Ḫalfān b. Qayṣar b. Sulaymān al-Ṣuḥārī, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic world. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, theology, and history. He was particularly renowned for his in-depth commentaries on the Quran and Hadith, which have been referenced by scholars for centuries. His works are considered essential readings for those seeking to understand the intricacies of Islamic law and theology. Despite the challenges of his time, his scholarly pursuits and writings have left a lasting mark on Islamic scholarship.

1061AhmadHabisYamani.bio: Ahmad Habis Yamani was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist, renowned for his profound knowledge in Islamic jurisprudence and law. He served as a judge, demonstrating unparalleled expertise in legal matters, which earned him widespread respect and admiration. His contributions to Islamic legal thought are considered invaluable, with his rulings and legal opinions still referenced by scholars and students of Islamic law today. His work not only reflects a deep understanding of Islamic principles but also showcases his commitment to justice and the application of Sharia in everyday life.

1061IbnMullaFarrukhRumi.bio: Ibn Mulla Farrukh Rumi was a distinguished scholar in the Hanafi school of Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic legal thought and jurisprudence are well-regarded, particularly in the realms of fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) and usul al-fiqh (principles of Islamic jurisprudence). His works, deeply rooted in the Hanafi tradition, serve as a testament to his profound understanding of Islamic law and its application. His scholarly efforts were focused on elucidating complex legal issues, making significant strides in the interpretation and application of Hanafi jurisprudence.

1061NajmDinGhazzi.bio: Naǧm al-Dīn Muḥammad al-Ġazzī, a distinguished scholar from Damascus, was renowned for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and history. His erudition in the Shafi'i school of thought was widely acknowledged. Among his notable works, the biographical dictionary 'Al-Kawākib al-Sā'irah bi A'yān al-Mi'a al-'Āshirah' stands out, offering invaluable insights into the lives of significant figures of the 10th Hijri century. His writings continue to be a vital source for scholars seeking to understand the intellectual and social dynamics of his era.

1062CabdAllahSharafi.bio: Cabd Allah Sharafi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist, renowned for his profound knowledge in Islamic jurisprudence and theology. He dedicated his life to teaching and writing, contributing significantly to the Islamic intellectual tradition. His works, which include comprehensive treatises on Islamic law and ethics, have been studied by scholars and students in Islamic studies for centuries. Sharafi's scholarly efforts were pivotal in elucidating complex legal and theological concepts, making them accessible to a broader audience. His dedication to Islamic scholarship has made his writings a valuable resource for those seeking to understand the intricacies of Islamic jurisprudence and moral philosophy.

1062NurDinMusawiCamili.bio: Nur Din Musawi Camili, also known as Muhammad Amin al-Istarabadi, was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist. He is best known for his critical work in the field of Usul al-Fiqh, the principles of Islamic jurisprudence. His most notable contribution is the development of the Akhbari school of thought within Shia Islam, which emphasizes the importance of hadiths over ijma (consensus) and qiyas (analogical reasoning). His writings and teachings have been influential in shaping the discourse on Islamic jurisprudence and theology.

1066IbnYusufZaynCabidinKurani.bio: Ibn Yusuf Zayn Cabidin Kurani was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic tradition, deeply rooted in the Hanafi school of thought. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-regarded, with his works serving as a cornerstone for students and scholars alike. Kurani's scholarly pursuits were not limited to jurisprudence; he also delved into Sufism, blending legalistic perspectives with mystical insights. His ability to bridge the gap between the exoteric and esoteric aspects of Islam made his writings particularly valuable to those seeking a comprehensive understanding of their faith.

1067HajjiKhalifa.bio: Ḥaǧǧī Ḫalīfa, Kātib Čelebī, a distinguished Ottoman scholar and historian, made significant contributions to the fields of geography, history, and bibliographical literature. He is best known for his monumental work, 'Kashf al-Ẓunūn 'an Asāmī al-Kutub wa-al-Funūn' (The Removal of Doubt from the Names of Books and the Arts), an extensive bibliographical encyclopedia that catalogs thousands of Arabic, Persian, and Turkish manuscripts. His efforts in compiling and categorizing works from various disciplines have provided invaluable resources for scholars and researchers, making him a pivotal figure in the preservation of Islamic intellectual heritage.

1068IbnCaliFuwati.bio: Ibn Cali Fuwati was a distinguished historian and biographer from the Islamic Golden Age. He dedicated his life to documenting the lives of scholars, poets, and notable figures of his time. His meticulous approach to gathering and presenting information made his works invaluable resources for understanding the cultural and intellectual landscape of his era. Among his contributions, his detailed accounts provide a window into the scholarly activities and social dynamics of the Muslim world, offering insights into the contributions of various individuals to the fields of science, literature, and philosophy.

1069IbnCammarShurunbulali.bio: Ibn Cammar Shurunbulali was an esteemed Hanafi jurist known for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence. His works are celebrated for their clarity and depth, making complex legal principles accessible to scholars and students alike. Among his notable contributions is the 'Nur al-Idah', a comprehensive guide on Hanafi fiqh that has been widely studied and taught across Islamic seminaries. His expertise in fiqh was matched by his dedication to teaching and his ability to distill vast legal concepts into understandable formats, making him a revered figure in Islamic scholarship.

1069MuhammadShawbari.bio: Muhammad Shawbari was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist, renowned for his profound contributions to the Maliki school of thought. His expertise in Islamic jurisprudence and dedication to teaching and writing significantly enriched the Islamic legal tradition. Shawbari's works, which include comprehensive treatises on Maliki law, are celebrated for their depth of analysis and clarity, serving as essential references for scholars and students of Islamic law. His scholarly efforts played a crucial role in the dissemination and development of Maliki jurisprudence across the Islamic world.

1069ShihabDinKhafaji.bio: Shihab Din Khafaji was an Egyptian Hanafi scholar renowned for his contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and literature. He authored several influential works, including a commentary on Jalal ad-Din al-Mahalli's and Jalal ad-Din as-Suyuti's Tafsir al-Jalalayn, known as 'Naseem al-Riyad'. This commentary is celebrated for its insightful analysis and has been a significant reference in Islamic studies. Khafaji's scholarly pursuits extended beyond jurisprudence, encompassing Arabic language and literature, demonstrating his versatile intellect and profound understanding of Islamic sciences.

1069ShihabDinQalyubi.bio: Shihab Din Qalyubi, originally named Ahmad ibn Ahmad ibn Salamah, was a distinguished Islamic jurist and scholar. He is renowned for his extensive contributions to the field of Islamic jurisprudence, particularly within the Shafi'i school of thought. His works, which include detailed commentaries on key Islamic texts, have been pivotal in the education and guidance of Muslim scholars and students. Qalyubi's scholarly efforts were focused on interpreting and elucidating complex Islamic legal principles, making them accessible to a broader audience. His dedication to Islamic scholarship has made his writings a valuable resource for those seeking to understand the intricacies of Islamic law.

1070MuhammadKibrit.bio: Muhammad Kibrit was a descendant of Sharaf al-Din bin Yahya al-Hamzi al-Husayni al-Mawlawi, known for his contributions to Islamic scholarship. He hailed from a lineage that was deeply rooted in Islamic learning and spirituality. His works, though not extensively documented in mainstream historical records, are believed to have contributed to the understanding and interpretation of Islamic texts. His familial background, being a part of the Husayni lineage, positioned him as a respected figure in Islamic circles, where his contributions were valued by scholars and students alike.

1071FadilTuniKhurasani.bio: Fadil Tuni Khurasani was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist, renowned for his profound knowledge in Islamic jurisprudence and ethics. He hailed from Khurasan, a region known for its rich intellectual heritage. His works contributed significantly to the understanding and interpretation of Islamic law and moral philosophy. Fadil Tuni's writings, characterized by their depth and clarity, served as essential references for scholars and students alike. His dedication to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences made him a respected figure among his contemporaries.

1071IbnFaqihFussaBacliDimashqi.bio: Ibn Faqih Fussa Bacli Dimashqi, also known as Abd al-Baqi ibn Abd al-Baqi ibn Abd al-Qadir al-Ba'li al-Azhari al-Dimashqi, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic world. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, history, and theology. He was deeply rooted in the Hanbali school of thought, reflecting in his scholarly works and teachings. His writings, characterized by depth and insight, served as valuable resources for scholars and students alike. His dedication to Islamic scholarship made him a respected figure among his contemporaries.

1072IbnAhmadMayyaraFasi.bio: Ibn Ahmad Mayyara Fasi was a distinguished Maliki jurist and scholar, deeply rooted in the rich intellectual tradition of Fes, Morocco. His profound understanding of Maliki jurisprudence and his ability to articulate complex legal principles in a clear and accessible manner made him a revered figure among his contemporaries. He authored several influential works, which have continued to be studied and referenced in the fields of Islamic law and ethics. His writings not only reflect his deep commitment to the Maliki school but also his broader engagement with the Islamic scholarly tradition.

1073CabdKarimFakun.bio: Cabd Karim Fakun was a scholar whose contributions to Islamic thought and jurisprudence remain influential. His extensive writings, which cover a wide range of subjects, demonstrate his deep understanding of Islamic law and theology. Fakun's work is characterized by its depth, precision, and innovative approach to interpreting Islamic texts. His scholarly efforts were dedicated to exploring the complexities of the Quran and Hadith, aiming to apply their teachings to the challenges of his time. His dedication to Islamic scholarship has made his works a valuable resource for scholars and students alike.

1073YusufBadiciDimashqi.bio: Yusuf Badici Dimashqi was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic world, known for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His works, deeply rooted in the Hanafi school of thought, have been instrumental in guiding Muslim scholars and students. His scholarly pursuits were not limited to jurisprudence alone; he also made significant contributions to the fields of hadith and Islamic philosophy. His writings, characterized by their depth and clarity, continue to be studied and revered in Islamic seminaries around the world.

1077Jurmuzi.bio: Jurmuzi, formally known as المطهر بن محمد الجرموزي, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. He dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Hadith, the sayings and actions of the Prophet Muhammad. His most notable contribution to Islamic literature is his compilation of Hadith, which has been widely recognized for its meticulous methodology and clarity in presentation. This work remains a vital reference for scholars and students of Islamic studies, reflecting his deep understanding and respect for the traditions of the Prophet.

1078RiyadZadah.bio: Riyad Zadah, originally named عبد اللطيف بن محمد بن مصطفى المتخلص بلطفي, was a distinguished Hanafi scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-regarded within the Hanafi school of thought. He authored several influential works that continue to be studied and referenced in Islamic scholarship. His expertise in fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) and his ability to articulate complex legal and theological concepts in a comprehensible manner made his writings invaluable to scholars and students alike.

1078ShaykhiZadahDamadAfandi.bio: Shaykhi Zadah Damad Afandi, originally named Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad ibn Sulayman, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. He was deeply rooted in the Hanafi school of thought, contributing significantly to Islamic jurisprudence. His works, which blend legal theory with practical application, have been influential in shaping the understanding of Islamic law. Among his notable contributions is his commentary on classical texts, where he elucidated complex legal principles in a manner accessible to scholars and students alike. His scholarly output remains a vital part of Islamic legal studies.

1079CumarDafriZuhri.bio: Cumar Dafri Zuhri, also known as عمر بن عمر الزهيري الحنفي in Arabic, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. He dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic jurisprudence and hadith. His works, deeply rooted in the Hanafi school of thought, contributed significantly to the understanding and interpretation of Islamic law. Zuhri's scholarly efforts were focused on bridging the gaps in legal and theological knowledge, making complex religious concepts accessible to a broader audience. His teachings continue to be a reference for students and scholars of Islamic studies.

1079HabalShacir.bio: Habal Shacir, originally known as الحسن بن علي بن جابر الهبل in Arabic, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic world. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, theology, and history. Shacir was renowned for his deep understanding of Islamic law and its application, as well as his insightful interpretations of Islamic texts. His works, which include commentaries on the Quran and Hadith, remain influential in Islamic scholarship. His dedication to the study and teaching of Islamic principles made him a respected figure among his contemporaries.

1079MuhammadIbnHasanIbnQasim.bio: Muhammad Ibn Hasan Ibn Qasim was a distinguished Islamic jurist and theologian. He is best known for his contributions to the Hanafi school of Islamic jurisprudence. His works delve deeply into the principles of fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence), offering insights that have been influential in shaping Islamic legal thought. His scholarly efforts were focused on interpreting and elaborating on the works of earlier jurists, aiming to make the Hanafi school's teachings more accessible and applicable to the evolving needs of the Muslim community.

1080IbnMuhammadBayquniDimashqi.bio: Ibn Muhammad Bayquni Dimashqi was a distinguished scholar in the field of Hadith. He is best known for his work 'Mandhumah al-Bayquniyyah,' a poem that succinctly outlines the classification of Hadith. This work has been celebrated for its clarity and brevity, making it a fundamental text for students of Islamic studies. His contributions are primarily in the realm of Hadith studies, where his efforts to simplify complex classifications have been widely appreciated. His scholarly work remains a staple in Islamic educational curricula, reflecting his expertise in the discipline.

1081MuhammadSalihMazandarani.bio: Muhammad Salih Mazandarani was a distinguished Islamic scholar who made significant contributions to the fields of hadith and jurisprudence. He is best known for his work 'Sharh Usul al-Kafi,' a comprehensive commentary on 'Al-Kafi,' one of the most important collections of hadith in Shia Islam. His scholarly efforts were focused on interpreting and elucidating the complex texts of hadith to make them more accessible to students and scholars alike. Mazandarani's dedication to Islamic scholarship has made his works a valuable resource for those seeking to understand the intricacies of Shia hadith and jurisprudence.

1082IbnShadqamMadani.bio: Ibn Shadqam Madani, formally known as ضامن بن شدقم المدني, was a distinguished scholar from Medina. His contributions to Islamic scholarship are noted for their depth and insight, particularly in the fields of Hadith and Islamic jurisprudence. His works, which include critical examinations and commentaries on various Islamic texts, have been studied by scholars and students alike. His scholarly pursuits and writings reflect a profound dedication to understanding and elucidating the complexities of Islamic teachings and law.

1082RaficDinNaini.bio: Rafic Din Naini was an influential Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the traditions of jurisprudence and theology. His contributions to Islamic thought are marked by his profound interpretations and commentaries on religious texts. Naini's works are characterized by a meticulous approach to the analysis of Islamic law and ethics, demonstrating a keen understanding of the complexities within Islamic jurisprudence. His scholarly output includes a range of texts that continue to be studied for their insightful perspectives on religious doctrine and legal theory.

1083IbnBalbanDimashqi.bio: Ibn Balban Dimashqi was a distinguished Hanbali scholar from Damascus. He is renowned for his contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and his efforts in compiling and explaining the Hanbali school of thought. His works are characterized by their depth in understanding and clarity, making them essential references for scholars and students alike. Among his notable contributions is his detailed commentary on the 'Mukhtasar al-Khiraqi,' a foundational text in Hanbali jurisprudence. His scholarly efforts have made him a respected figure in the study of Islamic law.

1083NasirIbrahimMuayyadi.bio: Nasir Ibrahim Muayyadi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and theologian. He was particularly renowned for his deep knowledge and critical analysis of the chains of narration, which are crucial for the authentication of Hadith. His scholarly efforts were dedicated to ensuring the accuracy and preservation of Islamic teachings for future generations.

1119MusaQulaybi.bio: Musa Qulaybi was a distinguished scholar in the Maliki school of Islamic jurisprudence. His profound understanding and interpretation of Islamic law made him a revered figure among his contemporaries. He dedicated his life to teaching and writing, contributing significantly to the body of Islamic legal literature. His works are still referenced for their depth of knowledge and clarity in explaining complex juridical issues. Musa Qulaybi's scholarly pursuits were not limited to jurisprudence; he also engaged in the study of hadith, which further solidified his status as a versatile Islamic scholar.

1120CaliKhanMadani.bio: Cali Khan Madani was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the traditions and teachings of Islam. His profound understanding and interpretation of Islamic jurisprudence and theology made him a revered figure among his contemporaries. Madani's contributions to Islamic literature include extensive writings on the principles of Sharia, ethics, and spirituality. His works are characterized by a deep insight into the Quran and Hadith, reflecting his dedication to the preservation and dissemination of Islamic knowledge. His scholarly pursuits were not confined to a single domain, as he engaged in teaching and writing across various Islamic sciences.

1120IbnMuhammadBurhanDinDimashqi.bio: Ibn Muhammad Burhan Din Dimashqi was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic tradition, deeply rooted in the Hanafi school of thought. His contributions spanned various fields, including Islamic jurisprudence, theology, and philosophy. He was particularly renowned for his insightful interpretations and commentaries on classical texts, which have been celebrated for their depth and clarity. His works served as a bridge, connecting the rich heritage of Islamic scholarship with the evolving needs of his contemporary society. Through his writings, he aimed to elucidate complex religious concepts and provide practical guidance on matters of faith and conduct.

1120IbnQasimIbnZakurFasi.bio: Ibn Qasim Ibn Zakur Fasi was a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence, history, and the Maliki school of thought. His contributions to Islamic literature include a variety of texts that delve into the intricacies of fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence), history, and ethics. His works are characterized by their depth of knowledge and clarity, making them valuable resources for scholars and students alike. His expertise in the Maliki legal tradition has made his writings a cornerstone for those studying Islamic law and its applications.

1121Mahuzi.bio: Al-Sheikh Al-Mahuzi was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply revered for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His extensive writings, characterized by insightful analysis and depth of knowledge, have been instrumental in shaping the understanding of Islamic law and ethics. His works, often used as primary texts in Islamic seminaries, reflect a meticulous approach to the Quran and Hadith studies, making him a revered figure among scholars and students of Islam.

1122MuhammadZurqani.bio: Muhammad Zurqani, a distinguished scholar in the Maliki school of thought, made significant contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and Hadith studies. He is best known for his comprehensive commentary on the Muwatta of Imam Malik, which is highly regarded for its depth of analysis and scholarly insight. Zurqani's work in harmonizing various Hadith reports and his meticulous approach to jurisprudential issues have made his writings a valuable resource for scholars and students alike. His expertise in the Maliki madhhab and his scholarly contributions continue to be celebrated in Islamic studies.

1124IbnCabdFattahTunukabuni.bio: Ibn Cabd Fattah Tunukabuni, also known as Al-Sarabi Al-Tunukabuni, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and literature are well-regarded among scholars and students of Islamic studies. He authored several influential works that delve into the intricacies of Islamic law and ethics, providing guidance and insight for both his contemporaries and future generations. His writings continue to be studied for their depth of knowledge and clarity of expression, reflecting his profound understanding of the Islamic tradition.

1125AhmadManqur.bio: Ahmad Manqur was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the rich traditions of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. Manqur's works are a testament to his profound understanding of the complexities of Islamic jurisprudence and his ability to articulate these complexities in a manner that is both accessible and enlightening. 1125AnsariLaknawi.bio: Ansari Laknawi, formally known as عبد العلي بن نظام الدين, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. Laknawi's works are characterized by their depth of analysis and clarity, making them essential readings in Islamic studies. 1125BashirFazari.bio: Bashir Fazari was a distinguished Islamic scholar and historian, renowned for his contributions to the fields of history and hadith. 1125IbnGhanimAzhariNafrawi.bio: Ibn Ghanim Azhari Nafrawi was a distinguished Maliki jurist and scholar, deeply rooted in the rich intellectual tradition of Islamic jurisprudence. His writings are celebrated for their clarity, depth, and meticulous adherence to the Maliki school of thought. 1125MirzaMuhammadMashhadi.bio: Mirza Muhammad Mashhadi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and author, renowned for his contributions to Shi'a Islamic thought and jurisprudence. His writings have served as a spiritual guide for generations, providing insights into the practices and beliefs of Shi'a Islam. His scholarly efforts have made him a respected figure in Islamic studies, with his works continuing to be studied and revered.

1126MuhammadHanbali.bio: Muhammad Hanbali was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Damascus. He was deeply rooted in the Hanbali school of thought, one of the four major Sunni legal schools. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-regarded, with his works serving as reference points for scholars and students alike. He was particularly known for his rigorous adherence to the texts of the Quran and Sunnah, emphasizing the importance of following the prophetic traditions in legal and ethical matters. His scholarly efforts were focused on clarifying and defending the principles of the Hanbali school.

His works are a blend of Sufism and Islamic jurisprudence, reflecting his profound understanding of both. Among his notable contributions is the 'Tafsir Ruh al-Bayan', a comprehensive exegesis of the Quran that intertwines classical interpretations with mystical insights. His writings continue to be a source of inspiration and guidance for those seeking to deepen their knowledge of Islamic spirituality and law.

1127KhayrDinIbnIlyas.bio: Ḫayr al-Dīn Ibn Ilyas was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist, renowned for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence. His scholarly works, deeply rooted in the Hanafi school of thought, have been instrumental in shaping the legal discourse within Islamic scholarship. His ability to interpret complex legal issues and present them in a comprehensible manner has made his writings a staple in Islamic legal studies. His dedication to the pursuit of knowledge and his commitment to the principles of Islamic law have left an indelible mark on the field of Islamic jurisprudence.

1129CaliAmirSancani.bio: Cali Amir Sancani was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Yemen. He was renowned for his profound knowledge in Hadith, the sayings and actions of the Prophet Muhammad. Sancani authored several influential works that contributed significantly to Islamic jurisprudence and Hadith studies. Among his notable works is 'Subul al-Salam', a comprehensive commentary on 'Bulugh al-Maram', which is highly regarded in Islamic scholarly circles for its insightful analysis and depth. His scholarly efforts were dedicated to elucidating complex religious texts, making them accessible to a broader audience.

1175MuhammadKarabisi.bio: Muhammad Karabisi, known in full as Muhammad Ja'far ibn Muhammad Tahir al-Khorasani al-Karabisi, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-regarded. He authored several influential works that delve into the complexities of Islamic law and ethics. His writings, characterized by their depth and clarity, continue to be studied and referenced in Islamic scholarly circles. Al-Karabisi's scholarly pursuits and teachings were rooted in a deep understanding of the Quran and Hadith, reflecting his commitment to the intellectual and spiritual traditions of Islam.

1175MuhammadSacidSunbul.bio: Muhammad Sacid Sunbul was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Mecca. He dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences, contributing significantly to the fields of Hadith and Fiqh. His scholarly works are still referenced by students and scholars of Islam, showcasing his deep understanding and interpretation of Islamic law and traditions. Sunbul's teachings and writings continue to be a source of knowledge and inspiration for those seeking to deepen their understanding of Islamic principles.

1176ShahWaliAllahDihlawi.bio: Shah Wali Allah Dihlawi was a multifaceted Islamic scholar who made significant contributions to Islamic thought and jurisprudence. He is renowned for his efforts to reconcile the rationalist and traditionalist approaches within Islamic scholarship. His works, including 'Hujjat Allah al-Baligha,' reflect a deep understanding of the Quran and Hadith, emphasizing the importance of ijtihad (independent reasoning) in understanding religious texts. Dihlawi's writings on Islamic law, spirituality, and society have been influential in shaping Islamic discourse. He advocated for a balanced approach to Islamic practice, emphasizing both the letter and the spirit of Islamic law.

1179AhmadShafici.bio: Ahmad Shafici, also known as أحمد بن علي الأزهري الشافعي, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic tradition. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and his deep understanding of the Shafi'i school of thought have been widely acknowledged. His works, which delve into the intricacies of Islamic law and theology, continue to be studied and respected. Shafici's scholarly pursuits were primarily focused on interpreting and elucidating the principles of the Shafi'i madhhab, making significant strides in the understanding and application of Islamic legal theory.

1179AhmadShihabDinSujaci.bio: Ahmad Shihab Din Sujaci, known in Arabic as أحمد السجاعي, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic tradition. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic studies, reflecting a deep understanding and interpretation of Islamic law and theology. Sujaci's works are characterized by their scholarly depth and have been influential in the study and practice of Islam. His expertise in the Shafi'i school of thought was particularly noted, making him a respected figure among his contemporaries and later scholars who sought to delve into Islamic jurisprudence and its application.

1180CabdAllahJazairi.bio: Cabd Allah Jazairi was a distinguished Islamic scholar known for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology. He authored several influential works that delved into the intricacies of fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) and hadith (sayings and actions of Prophet Muhammad), enriching the Islamic scholarly tradition. His writings, characterized by their depth and clarity, served as essential references for scholars and students alike. Among his notable contributions is 'Lawami' al-Anwar al-Bahiyya wa Sawati' al-Asrar al-Athariyya', a comprehensive work on Hanbali creed and Sufism. 1189ShihabDinBacli.bio: Shihab Din Bacli, originally named Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Ahmad al-Bacli, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. He was particularly renowned for his ability to interpret and elucidate complex Islamic legal principles, making them accessible to a broader audience. His dedication to the preservation and dissemination of Islamic knowledge marked him as a respected figure among his contemporaries.

1191Kawkabani.bio: Kawkabani, known fully as الحافظ الفقيه صفي الدين أحمد بن عبد الله الخزرجي الأنصاري اليمني, was a distinguished scholar in the fields of Hadith and Fiqh. His works, which include critical examinations and commentaries on various Islamic texts, have been instrumental in the study and understanding of Islamic law and prophetic traditions. His dedication to Islamic scholarship has made his writings a valuable resource for students and scholars alike.

1192AbuMarahimCaydarus.bio: Abu Marahim Caydarus was a distinguished Islamic scholar and mystic. His ability to blend spiritual insights with practical guidance made his teachings accessible and revered among his contemporaries and later generations of scholars and mystics.

He is best known for his work "Kashf al-Mukhadarat fi Sharh Akhsar al-Mukhtasarat," a comprehensive commentary on Islamic legal principles. 1193HusaynWarthilani.bio: Husayn Warthilani was an Islamic scholar from Warthilan, a region in Algeria. He is renowned for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and Sufism. His works often delve into the intricacies of Maliki law, reflecting his deep understanding and commitment to the Maliki school of thought. Warthilani's writings also explore the spiritual dimensions of Islam, offering insights into the practices and philosophies of Sufism. His scholarly output includes a variety of texts that have been influential in both the Maghreb and the broader Islamic world, showcasing his versatility and depth as a scholar.

1195CabdRahmanAnsari.bio: Cabd Rahman Ansari was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Medina, known for his deep expertise in Hanafi jurisprudence. His scholarly contributions include a wide range of Islamic sciences, with a particular focus on Fiqh, Hadith, and Tafsir. Ansari was renowned for his ability to articulate complex Islamic legal theories and principles in a manner that was accessible to scholars and students alike. His works continue to be studied and respected for their clarity and depth of insight into Islamic law and theology.

1198AhmadIbnSalahKhatib.bio: Ahmad Ibn Salah Khatib was a distinguished Islamic scholar who made significant contributions to the field of Hadith and its sciences. His efforts in categorizing and evaluating the authenticity of Hadiths have been instrumental in shaping Islamic jurisprudence and academic thought. 1200CabdAllahIbnBashirHadrami.bio: Cabd Allah Ibn Bashir Hadrami was a distinguished Islamic scholar. His works, deeply rooted in the Hadrami tradition, explore various aspects of Islamic law and ethics. His scholarly approach combined rigorous analysis with a deep respect for the traditions of Islam, making his writings valuable resources for those seeking to understand the complexities of Islamic jurisprudence.

1200CabdNabiAhmadNagari.bio: Cabd Nabi Ahmad Nagari was a distinguished Islamic jurist and scholar. He is renowned for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and legal theory. His works, deeply rooted in the principles of Sharia, have been instrumental in guiding legal and ethical discussions within the Islamic community. Nagari's scholarly efforts were focused on interpreting and applying Islamic law in ways that were both innovative and respectful of tradition. 1200CabdNabiQazwini.bio: Cabd Nabi Qazwini was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist, renowned for his profound knowledge in Islamic jurisprudence and theology. He dedicated his life to teaching and writing, contributing significantly to the Islamic intellectual tradition. His works, which include comprehensive treatises on Islamic law and ethics, have been widely studied and respected in Islamic scholarly circles. Qazwini's expertise in the intricacies of Islamic jurisprudence made him a revered figure among his contemporaries and students, who sought his guidance in understanding complex religious and legal matters.

1200HannaDiyab.bio: Hanna Diyab was a Syrian storyteller and writer from Aleppo. He is best known for his crucial role in the transmission of Middle Eastern folk tales to Europe. Diyab's journey to Paris, where he met Antoine Galland, led to the inclusion of several iconic stories, such as 'Aladdin' and 'Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves,' in Galland's French translation of 'One Thousand and One Nights.' His personal narrative and the tales he shared have significantly contributed to the global appreciation of Middle Eastern literature and folklore.

1200HaydarCaliIbnMuhammadShirwani.bio: Haydar Cali Ibn Muhammad Shirwani was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist. He hailed from Shirwan, a region known for its rich intellectual heritage. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology were profound, with his works being studied by scholars and students across the Islamic world. Shirwani's writings delve into the intricacies of Islamic law and ethics, offering insights that have been valued for their depth and clarity. His scholarly output reflects a deep engagement with the Islamic tradition, making him a respected figure in the annals of Islamic scholarship.

1200IbnAhmadSafiDinBukhari.bio: Ibn Ahmad Safi Din Bukhari was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the Hanafi jurisprudence and Athari creed. His scholarly contributions spanned various Islamic sciences, reflecting his profound understanding and dedication to Islamic teachings. He was known for his unique approach to Islamic jurisprudence and hadith studies, making significant contributions to these fields. His works are still referenced by scholars and students of Islam, showcasing his enduring influence in the Islamic scholarly tradition. His lineage, tracing back to the noble family of the Prophet Muhammad, added to his esteemed status among his contemporaries.

1200Nisari.bio: Nisari was a distinguished historian and theologian within the Ismaili tradition. He is best known for his comprehensive work on the history and doctrines of the Ismailis, providing invaluable insights into the community's development and beliefs. His writings, characterized by meticulous research and a clear, engaging style, serve as crucial resources for scholars studying Ismaili history and Islamic thought. Nisari's contributions have been instrumental in preserving the rich heritage of the Ismaili community, offering a window into their intellectual and spiritual life.

1200ShaykhCabdHusayn.bio: Shaykh Cabd Husayn was a revered Islamic scholar who dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic sciences. He was known for his profound understanding of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. Throughout his career, he authored several influential works that contributed significantly to the Islamic scholarly tradition. His writings, characterized by their depth and clarity, continue to be studied and respected in Islamic academic circles. Shaykh Cabd Husayn's commitment to education and his scholarly achievements made him a respected figure among his contemporaries and students.

1201AhmadDardidAbuBarakat.bio: Ahmad Dardid Abu Barakat, known in Islamic scholarship for his profound contributions to Maliki jurisprudence, authored several influential texts. Among his works, the most celebrated is 'Aqrab al-Masalik ila Madhhab Malik,' a comprehensive guide on Maliki fiqh. His writings, characterized by clarity and depth, served as essential resources for scholars and students alike. His dedication to Islamic law and its principles made him a respected figure in the scholarly community, with his works continuing to be studied and referenced in Islamic jurisprudence discussions.

1204SulaymanJamal.bio: Sulayman Jamal, also known as Zakariya al-Ansari, was a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence and theology. He made significant contributions to the Shafi'i school of thought. His works, deeply rooted in Islamic tradition, include comprehensive commentaries on the Quran and Hadith. Among his notable works is a commentary on the 'Minhaj al-Talibin', a key text in Shafi'i fiqh, which remains a reference for scholars and students alike. His scholarly efforts bridged various Islamic sciences, making his writings invaluable for those seeking to understand the intricacies of Islamic law and theology.

1205MurtadaZabidi.bio: Murtada Zabidi was a distinguished Islamic scholar renowned for his profound contributions to Arabic lexicography and Islamic jurisprudence. His magnum opus, 'Taj al-Arus min Jawahir al-Qamus,' stands as a monumental work in the field of Arabic language, expanding and elaborating upon the celebrated 'Qamus al-Muhit' by Al-Firuzabadi. Zabidi's erudition extended beyond lexicography, encompassing a wide range of Islamic sciences, which he adeptly taught and wrote about. His scholarly pursuits took him across the Islamic world, where he engaged with various intellectual traditions, enriching his works with a diverse spectrum of knowledge.

1205WahidBihbahani.bio: Wahid Bihbahani was a central figure in the revival of Twelver Shi'a Islam, marking a turning point in its doctrinal and jurisprudential development. He is best known for his efforts in consolidating the Usuli school of thought, which emphasizes the role of mujtahids in interpreting the Quran and Hadith. His debates and scholarly works played a crucial role in shaping the intellectual landscape of Shi'a Islam, advocating for the dynamic application of Islamic principles to address contemporary issues. His teachings and scholarly contributions continue to influence Shi'a thought and jurisprudence.

1206IbnCabdWahhab.bio: Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab was a religious leader and theologian from Najd, in present-day Saudi Arabia. He is best known for founding the Islamic reform movement that sought to purify Islam by returning to what he believed were its original principles as practiced by the Prophet Muhammad and his companions. This movement emphasized the importance of Tawhid (the oneness of God), and vehemently opposed shirk (the association of partners with God) and bid'ah (innovations in religion). His works include 'Kitab al-Tawhid' and 'Kashf al-Shubuhat', which articulate his theological and legal positions.

1206IbnCaliSabbanShafici.bio: Ibn Cali Sabban Shafici was a distinguished Islamic scholar within the Shafi'i school of thought. He dedicated his life to the study and teaching of Islamic jurisprudence, theology, and ethics. His works are considered a valuable contribution to Islamic literature, particularly in the areas of fiqh (Islamic jurisprudence) and usul al-fiqh (principles of Islamic jurisprudence). Among his notable contributions is a comprehensive encyclopedia that serves as a reference for scholars and students of Islamic studies. His writings reflect a deep understanding of the Shafi'i madhhab, showcasing his expertise and devotion to Islamic scholarship.

1206Muradi.bio: Al-Murādī, also known as Abū al-Muwaddaṭ Muḥammad Khalīl b. Alī b. Muḥammad b. Muḥammad Murād b. Alī al-Murādī al-Ḥusaynī al-Ḥanafī, was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic tradition. His contributions spanned various fields of Islamic sciences, including jurisprudence, theology, and Sufism. Al-Murādī was particularly renowned for his deep understanding of Hanafi jurisprudence, and his works are considered a valuable resource for scholars and students alike. His writings, characterized by their depth and clarity, continue to be studied and referenced for their insightful interpretations of Islamic law and spirituality.

1207IbnAhmadCabdQadirKawkabani.bio: Ibn Ahmad Cabd Qadir Kawkabani was a distinguished scholar in the Islamic tradition. He hailed from the Kawkaban area, aligning with the Shafi'i school of thought. His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and scholarship are noted for their depth and insight. His works, deeply rooted in the classical traditions, continue to be studied for their rigorous analysis and scholarly precision. His adherence to the Shafi'i madhhab is particularly significant, reflecting his commitment to the principles and methodologies of Islamic law as interpreted within this legal framework.

1208SulaymanJamzuriAffandi.bio: Sulayman Jamzuri Affandi, a distinguished scholar in Islamic jurisprudence, made significant contributions to the field through his writings. He is best known for his work on the principles of Islamic jurisprudence, which has been a reference point for scholars and students alike. His expertise in the Hanafi school of thought allowed him to develop a comprehensive understanding of Islamic law, which he articulated in his texts. 1209MuhammadMahdiNaraqi.bio: Muhammad Mahdi Naraqi was an esteemed Islamic philosopher and theologian. He hailed from a lineage of scholars and contributed significantly to the intellectual tradition of Islam. Naraqi was particularly known for his works in ethics, philosophy, and mysticism. Among his notable contributions is the 'Jami' al-Sa'adat' (The Collector of Felicities), a comprehensive treatise on Islamic ethics and morality. His writings blend philosophical insights with Islamic theology, offering a nuanced perspective on the human soul, its perfection, and the path to achieving spiritual enlightenment.

1209SulaymanBakShawi.bio: Sulayman Bak Shawi was a distinguished scholar and historian, renowned for his contributions to the field of Islamic history. His works are celebrated for their depth of research and clarity of insight, offering valuable perspectives on the complexities of Islamic governance and society. Shawi's writings, characterized by meticulous scholarship and a profound understanding of Islamic law and history, serve as essential references for scholars and students alike. His dedication to the preservation and interpretation of Islamic history has made his works a cornerstone in the study of the Islamic world.

1210SulaymanAkhIbnCabdWahhab.bio: Sulayman Akh Ibn Cabd Wahhab was a distinguished Islamic scholar, known for his critical stance against the teachings of his brother, Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab. He authored several works articulating his disagreements, most notably in his treatise, 'Divine Thunderbolts in Refuting the Wahhabis.' His writings provide a comprehensive critique of the doctrinal positions held by his brother, offering an alternative perspective on Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His scholarly contributions are considered significant in the context of Islamic discourse and debates of his time.

1211KazimUzri.bio: Kazim Uzri, known in Arabic as الشيخ كاظم الأزري التميمي, was a distinguished Islamic scholar. Uzri's scholarly pursuits were deeply rooted in the interpretation of Islamic texts, aiming to elucidate complex religious principles for broader understanding. His dedication to Islamic education and scholarship has made his writings a valuable asset for students and scholars alike, particularly those focusing on Shia jurisprudential thought.

His contributions to Islamic jurisprudence and theology are well-documented through his extensive writings and discourses. Garsifi's scholarly work primarily focused on interpreting Islamic law and the principles of faith, aiming to elucidate complex religious matters for the broader Muslim community. 1216HusaynBahraniAlCusfur.bio: Husayn Bahrani Al Cusfur was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Bahrain. He was renowned for his deep understanding of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His scholarly contributions include extensive writings on Islamic law, ethics, and philosophy. Al Cusfur was particularly noted for his ability to interpret and explain complex Islamic legal and theological concepts in a manner that was accessible to a broad audience. 1218IbnMuhammadIbnSacud.bio: Ibn Muhammad Ibn Saud was a central figure in the establishment and expansion of the First Saudi State. His leadership was marked by significant military campaigns that extended his control over a vast territory in the Arabian Peninsula. Under his rule, the foundations for the Saudi dynasty were laid, and he played a crucial role in spreading the reformist teachings of Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab, thereby influencing the religious and political landscape of the region. His governance was characterized by efforts to implement a form of governance based on his interpretation of Islamic law.

1218SalihFulani.bio: Salih Fulani, originally known as صالح بن محمد بن نوح العمري, was a distinguished scholar in the Maliki school of Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic scholarship were profound, with his works being recognized for their depth in the Maliki jurisprudence. Fulani's expertise was not limited to jurisprudence; he was also well-versed in other Islamic sciences, which allowed him to contribute significantly to the body of Islamic knowledge during his lifetime. 1219TalibBartiliWalati.bio: Talib Bartili Walati was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the rich traditions of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His works reflect a profound understanding of the complexities of Islamic law and ethics, serving as a bridge between classical Islamic thought and contemporary discussions. 1221HusaynSiyaghi.bio: Husayn Siyaghi was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist, renowned for his profound contributions to Islamic jurisprudence. His expertise in the intricacies of Islamic jurisprudence and his ability to interpret complex legal issues have made his writings a valuable resource for scholars and students alike. Among his contributions, his meticulous compilations and commentaries on Hadith literature stand out, serving as essential references for scholars and students of Islamic studies. 1224IbnCajiba.bio: Ibn 'Ajiba, a Sufi scholar from the Shadhili order, was renowned for his profound contributions to Islamic mysticism and exegesis. His most celebrated work, 'Al-Bahr al-Madid fi Tafsir al-Qur'an al-Majid,' stands as a monumental commentary on the Quran, blending traditional interpretations with Sufi insights. Additionally, his autobiography, 'Al-Ibriz,' detailing his spiritual journey and experiences, has been a source of inspiration for many. His writings, deeply rooted in the teachings of the Shadhili order, continue to be studied for their spiritual depth and insight.

1225BahrCulum.bio: Bahr Culum was a distinguished Islamic scholar and jurist, deeply revered within the Twelver Shi'a community. He was known for his profound knowledge in jurisprudence, principles of jurisprudence, and hadith. His scholarly contributions include a wide range of Islamic sciences, making him a central figure in the Hawza of Najaf. His works continue to be a reference for students and scholars alike, reflecting his deep understanding and interpretation of Islamic law and theology.

1225IbnGhannamMalikiNajdi.bio: Ibn Ghannam Maliki Najdi, originally from Al-Ahsa in the Najd region, was a distinguished scholar in the Maliki school of Islamic jurisprudence. His contributions to Islamic scholarship are vast, with a particular focus on the interpretation and application of Maliki jurisprudence. His works, deeply rooted in the classical traditions of Islamic law, serve as a reference for scholars and students of Islam. His dedication to the Maliki school has left a lasting mark on the study and practice of Islamic law.

1225IbnNasirNajdi.bio: Ibn Nasir Najdi, a distinguished scholar in the Hanbali school of thought, made significant contributions to Islamic jurisprudence. His works, deeply rooted in the Hanbali tradition, reflect a profound understanding of Islamic law and theology. He was known for his meticulous approach to religious texts, emphasizing the importance of direct engagement with the Quran and Sunnah. His scholarly output includes a range of texts that continue to be studied for their insights into Hanbali jurisprudence and their application to contemporary Islamic legal issues.

1225ThanaAllahPanipati.bio: Thana Allah Panipati, known in Arabic as المظهري، محمد ثناء الله, was a distinguished Islamic scholar from Panipat, India. He is renowned for his deep insights into Sufism and his scholarly contributions to Islamic jurisprudence. Among his notable works is the 'Tafsir Mazhari', a comprehensive exegesis of the Quran that combines jurisprudential insights with Sufi interpretations, making it a unique contribution to Islamic literature. His writings continue to be a source of inspiration and guidance for scholars and students of Islam.

1226AhmadBarbir.bio: Ahmad Barbir was a distinguished Islamic scholar, deeply rooted in the rich traditions of Islamic jurisprudence and theology. His scholarly contributions spanned various aspects of Islamic studies, including jurisprudence, theology, and the interpretation of Islamic texts. Barbir was known for his profound understanding of the complexities of Islamic law and his ability to articulate and explain intricate legal and theological concepts with clarity and depth.
